castGroup.head: Lords attending on the Princess of France

div.head: Act 1, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter FERDINAND, king of NAVARRE, Berowne, LONGAVILLE, and Dumaine.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Let fame, that all hunt after in their lives,
Live registered upon our brazen tombs
And then grace us in the disgrace of death;
When, spite of cormorant devouring Time,
The endeavour of this present breath may buy
That honour which shall bate his scythe's keen edge
And make us heirs of all eternity.
Therefore, brave conquerors, — for so you are,
That war against your own affections
And the huge army of the world's desires, —
Our late edict shall strongly stand in force:
Navarre shall be the wonder of the world;
Our court shall be a little Academe,
Still and contemplative in living art.
You three, Berowne, Dumaine, and Longaville,
Have sworn for three years' term to live with me
My fellow scholars and to keep those statutes
That are recorded in this schedule here:
Your oaths are passed; and now subscribe your names,
That his own hand may strike his honour down
That violates the smallest branch herein:
If you are armed to do as sworn to do,
Subscribe to your deep oaths, and keep it too.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: I am resolved; 'tis but a three years' fast:
The mind shall banquet, though the body pine:
Fat paunches have lean pates, and dainty bits
Make rich the ribs, but bankrupt quite the wits.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: My loving lord, Dumaine is mortified:
The grosser manner of these world's delights
He throws upon the gross world's baser slaves:
To love, to wealth, to pomp, I pine and die;
With all these living in philosophy.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: I can but say their protestation over;
So much, dear liege, I have already sworn,
That is, to live and study here three years.
But there are other strict observances;
As, not to see a woman in that term,
Which I hope well is not enrolled there;
And one day in a week to touch no food
And but one meal on every day beside,
The which I hope is not enrolled there;
And then, to sleep but three hours in the night,
And not be seen to wink of all the day —
When I was wont to think no harm all night
And make a dark night too of half the day —
Which I hope well is not enrolled there:
O, these are barren tasks, too hard to keep,
Not to see ladies, study, fast, not sleep!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Your oath is passed to pass away from these.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Let me say no, my liege, an if you please:
I only swore to study with your grace
And stay here in your court for three years' space.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: You swore to that, Berowne, and to the rest.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: By yea and nay, sir, then I swore in jest.
What is the end of study? let me know.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Why, that to know, which else we should not know.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Things hid and barred, you mean, from common sense?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Ay, that is study's godlike recompense.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Come on, then; I will swear to study so,
To know the thing I am forbid to know:
As thus, — to study where I well may dine,
When I to feast expressly am forbid;
Or study where to meet some mistress fine,
When mistresses from common sense are hid;
Or, having sworn too hard-a-keeping oath,
Study to break it and not break my troth.
If study's gain be thus and this be so,
Study knows that which yet it doth not know:
Swear me to this, and I will ne'er say no.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: These be the stops that hinder study quite
And train our intellects to vain delight.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Why, all delights are vain; but that most vain,
Which with pain purchased doth inherit pain:
As, painfully to pore upon a book
To seek the light of truth; while truth the while
Doth falsely blind the eyesight of his look:
Light seeking light doth light of light beguile:
So, ere you find where light in darkness lies,
Your light grows dark by losing of your eyes.
Study me how to please the eye indeed
By fixing it upon a fairer eye,
Who dazzling so, that eye shall be his heed
And give him light that it was blinded by.
Study is like the heaven's glorious sun
That will not be deep searched with saucy looks:
Small have continual plodders ever won
Save base authority from others' books.
These earthly godfathers of heaven's lights
That give a name to every fixed star
Have no more profit of their shining nights
Than those that walk and wot not what they are.
Too much to know is to know nought but fame;
And every godfather can give a name.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: How well he's read, to reason against reading!

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Proceeded well, to stop all good proceeding!

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: He weeds the corn and still lets grow the weeding.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: The spring is near when green geese are a-breeding.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: How follows that?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Fit in his place and time.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: In reason nothing.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Something then in rhyme.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Berowne is like an envious sneaping frost,
That bites the first-born infants of the spring.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Well, say I am; why should proud summer boast
Before the birds have any cause to sing?
Why should I joy in any abortive birth?
At Christmas I no more desire a rose
Than wish a snow in May's new-fangled shows;
But like of each thing that in season grows.
So you, to study now it is too late,
Climb o'er the house to unlock the little gate.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Well, sit you out: go home, Berowne: adieu.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: No, my good lord; I have sworn to stay with you:
And though I have for barbarism spoke more
Than for that angel knowledge you can say,
Yet confident I'll keep what I have sworn
And bide the penance of each three years' day.
Give me the paper; let me read the same;
And to the strict'st decrees I'll write my name.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: How well this yielding rescues thee from shame!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: “Item, That no woman shall come within a mile of my
court:” Hath this been proclaimed?

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.ab: Four days ago.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Let's see the penalty.
“On pain of losing her tongue.” Who devised this
penalty?

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Marry, that did I.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Sweet lord, and why?

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: To fright them hence with that dread penalty.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: A dangerous law against gentility!
sp.ab: “Item, If any man be seen to talk with a woman
within the term of three years, he shall endure
such public shame as the rest of the court can
possible devise.”
sp.l: This article, my liege, yourself must break;
For well you know here comes in embassy
The French king's daughter with yourself to speak —
A maid of grace and complete majesty —
About surrender up of Aquitaine
To her decrepit, sick and bedrid father:
Therefore this article is made in vain,
Or vainly comes the admired princess hither.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: What say you, lords? why, this was quite forgot.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: So study evermore is overshot:
While it doth study to have what it would
It doth forget to do the thing it should,
And when it hath the thing it hunteth most,
'Tis won as towns with fire, so won, so lost.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: We must of force dispense with this decree;
She must lie here on mere necessity.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Necessity will make us all forsworn
Three thousand times within this three years' space;
For every man with his affects is born,
Not by might mastered but by special grace:
If I break faith, this word shall speak for me;
I am forsworn on “mere necessity.”
So to the laws at large I write my name: Subscribes.
And he that breaks them in the least degree
Stands in attainder of eternal shame:
Suggestions are to other as to me;
But I believe, although I seem so loath,
I am the last that will last keep his oath.
But is there no quick recreation granted?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Ay, that there is. Our court, you know, is haunted
With a refined traveller of Spain;
A man in all the world's new fashion planted,
That hath a mint of phrases in his brain;
One who the music of his own vain tongue
Doth ravish like enchanting harmony;
A man of complements, whom right and wrong
Have chose as umpire of their mutiny:
This child of fancy, that Armado hight,
For interim to our studies shall relate
In high-born words the worth of many a knight
From tawny Spain lost in the world's debate.
How you delight, my lords, I know not, I;
But, I protest, I love to hear him lie
And I will use him for my minstrelsy.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Armado is a most illustrious wight,
A man of fire-new words, fashion's own knight.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Costard the swain and he shall be our sport;
And so to study, three years is but short. Enter DULL with a letter, and COSTARD.

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: Which is the duke's own person?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: This, fellow: what wouldst?

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: I myself reprehend his own person, for I am his
grace's farborough; but I would see his own person in
flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: This is he.

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: Signior Arme — Arme — commends you. There's villainy
abroad: this letter will tell you more.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Sir, the contempts thereof are as touching me.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: A letter from the magnificent Armado.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: How low soever the matter, I hope in God for high
words.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.ab: A high hope for a low heaven: God grant us patience!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: To hear? or forbear hearing?

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.ab: To hear meekly, sir, and to laugh moderately; or to
forbear both.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Well, sir, be it as the style shall give us cause to
climb in the merriness.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: The matter is to me, sir, as concerning Jaquenetta.
The manner of it is, I was taken with the manner.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: In what manner?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: In manner and form following, sir; all those
three: I was seen with her in the manor-house,
sitting with her upon the form, and taken following
her into the park; which, put together, is in
manner and form following. Now, sir, for the
manner, — it is the manner of a man to speak to a woman:
for the form, — in some form.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: For the following, sir?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: As it shall follow in my correction: and God defend
the right!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: Will you hear this letter with attention?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: As we would hear an oracle.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Such is the simplicity of man to hearken after the
flesh.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: “Great deputy, the welkin's vicegerent and sole
dominator of Navarre, my soul's earth's god, and
body's fostering patron.”

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Not a word of Costard yet.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: “So it is,” —

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: It may be so: but if he say it is so, he is, in
telling true, but so.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: Peace!

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Be to me and every man that dares not fight!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: No words!

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Of other men's secrets, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: “So it is, besieged with sable coloured melancholy,
I did commend the black oppressing humour to the
most wholesome physic of thy health-giving air;
and, as I am a gentleman, betook myself to walk.
The time when. About the sixth hour; when beasts
most graze, birds best peck, and men sit down to
that nourishment which is called supper: so much
for the time when. Now for the ground which;
which, I mean, I walked upon: it is ycleped thy
park. Then for the place where; where, I mean,
I did encounter that obscene and most preposterous
event, that draweth from my snow-white pen the
ebon-coloured ink, which here thou viewest,
beholdest, surveyest, or seest; but to the place
where; it standeth north-north-east and by east
from the west corner of thy curious-knotted
garden: there did I see that low-spirited swain, that
base minnow of thy mirth,” —

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Me?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: “that unlettered small-knowing soul,” —

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Me?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: “that shallow vassal,” —

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Still me?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: “which, as I remember, hight Costard, —

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: O, me!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: “sorted and consorted, contrary to thy established
proclaimed edict and continent canon, which
with, — O, with — but with this I passion to say
wherewith, —

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: With a wench.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: “with a child of our grandmother Eve, a female;
or, for thy more sweet understanding, a woman.
Him I, as my ever-esteemed duty pricks me on,
have sent to thee, to receive the meed of
punishment, by thy sweet grace's officer, Anthony
Dull; a man of good repute, carriage, bearing, and
estimation.”

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: Me, an't shall please you; I am Anthony Dull.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: “For Jaquenetta, — so is the weaker vessel called
which I apprehended with the aforesaid swain, — I
keep her as a vessel of thy law's fury; and shall,
at the least of thy sweet notice, bring her to
trial. Thine, in all compliments of devoted and
heart-burning heat of duty. DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO.”

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: This is not so well as I looked for, but the best that
ever I heard.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: Ay, the best for the worst. But, sirrah, what say you
to this?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Sir, I confess the wench.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: Did you hear the proclamation?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: I do confess much of the hearing it but little of the
marking of it.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: It was proclaimed a year's imprisonment, to be taken
with a wench.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: I was taken with none, sir: I was taken with a damsel.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: Well, it was proclaimed “damsel.”

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: This was no damsel, neither, sir; she was a virgin.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: It is so varied, too; for it was proclaimed “virgin.”

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: If it were, I deny her virginity: I was taken with a
maid.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: This maid will not serve your turn, sir.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: This maid will serve my turn, sir.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: Sir, I will pronounce your sentence: you shall fast a
week with bran and water.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: I had rather pray a month with mutton and porridge.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: And Don Armado shall be your keeper.
My lord Berowne, see him delivered o'er:
And go we, lords, to put in practice that
Which each to other hath so strongly sworn.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: I'll lay my head to any good man's hat,
These oaths and laws will prove an idle scorn.
Sirrah, come on.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: I suffer for the truth, sir; for true it is, I
was taken with Jaquenetta, and Jaquenetta is a
true girl; and therefore welcome the sour cup of
prosperity! Affliction may one day smile again; and
till then, sit thee down, sorrow!

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Boy, what sign is it when a man of great spirit grows
melancholy?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: A great sign, sir, that he will look sad.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Why, sadness is one and the selfsame thing, dear imp.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: No, no; O Lord, sir, no.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: How canst thou part sadness and melancholy, my tender
juvenal?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: By a familiar demonstration of the working, my tough
signor.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Why tough signor? why tough signor?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Why tender juvenal? why tender juvenal?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I spoke it, tender juvenal, as a congruent
epitheton appertaining to thy young days, which we may
nominate tender.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: And I, tough senior, as an appertinent title to your
old time, which we may name tough.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Pretty and apt.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: How mean you, sir? I pretty, and my saying apt? or I
apt, and my saying pretty?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Thou pretty, because little.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Little pretty, because little. Wherefore apt?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: And therefore apt, because quick.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Speak you this in my praise, master?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: In thy condign praise.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: I will praise an eel with the same praise.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: What, that an eel is ingenious?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: That an eel is quick.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I do say thou art quick in answers: thou heatest my
blood.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: I am answered, sir.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I love not to be crossed.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: He speaks the mere contrary; crosses love not him.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I have promised to study three years with the duke.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: You may do it in an hour, sir.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: How many is one thrice told?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I am ill at reckoning; it fitteth the spirit of a
tapster.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: You are a gentleman and a gamester, sir.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I confess both: they are both the varnish of a
complete man.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Then, I am sure, you know how much the gross sum of
deuce-ace amounts to.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: It doth amount to one more than two.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Which the base vulgar do call three.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: True.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Why, sir, is this such a piece of study? Now here
is three studied, ere ye'll thrice wink: and how
easy it is to put “years' to the word “three,”
and study three years in two words, the dancing horse
will tell you.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: A most fine figure!

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: To prove you a cipher.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I will hereupon confess I am in love: and as it
is base for a soldier to love, so am I in love
with a base wench. If drawing my sword against
the humour of affection would deliver me from
the reprobate thought of it, I would take Desire
prisoner, and ransom him to any French courtier
for a new-devised curtsy. I think scorn to sigh:
methinks I should outswear Cupid. Comfort, me, boy:
what great men have been in love?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Hercules, master.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Most sweet Hercules! More authority, dear boy,
name more; and, sweet my child, let them be men of
good repute and carriage.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Samson, master: he was a man of good carriage,
great carriage, for he carried the town gates on his
back like a porter: and he was in love.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: O well-knit Samson! strong-jointed Samson! I do
excel thee in my rapier as much as thou didst me
in carrying gates. I am in love, too. Who was Samson's
love, my dear Moth?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: A woman, master.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Of what complexion?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Of all the four, or the three, or the two, or one of
the four.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Tell me precisely of what complexion.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Of the sea-water green, sir.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Is that one of the four complexions?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: As I have read, sir; and the best of them too.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Green indeed is the colour of lovers; but to have
a love of that colour, methinks Samson had small
reason for it. He surely affected her for her wit.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: It was so, sir; for she had a green wit.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: My love is most immaculate white and red.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Most maculate thoughts, master, are masked under such
colours.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Define, define, well-educated infant.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: My father's wit and my mother's tongue, assist me!

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Sweet invocation of a child; most pretty and
pathetical!

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: If she be made of white and red,
Her faults will ne'er be known,
For blush in cheeks by faults are bred
And fears by pale white shown:
Then if she fear, or be to blame,
By this you shall not know,
For still her cheeks possess the same
Which native she doth owe.
sp.ab: A dangerous rhyme, master, against the reason of white
and red.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Is there not a ballad, boy, of the King and the
Beggar?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: The world was very guilty of such a ballad some
three ages since: but I think now 'tis not to be
found; or, if it were, it would neither serve for the
writing nor the tune.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I will have that subject newly writ o'er, that
I may example my digression by some mighty
precedent. Boy, I do love that country girl that
I took in the park with the rational hind Costard: she
deserves well.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: To be whipped; and yet a better love than my master.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Sing, boy; my spirit grows heavy in love.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: And that's great marvel, loving a light wench.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I say, sing.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Forbear till this company be past.

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: Sir, the duke's pleasure is, that you keep Costard
safe: and you must suffer him to take no delight
nor no penance; but 'a must fast three days a
week. For this damsel, I must keep her at the
park: she is allowed for the day-woman. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I do betray myself with blushing. Maid!

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.ab: Man?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I will visit thee at the lodge.

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.ab: That's hereby.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I know where it is situate.

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.ab: Lord, how wise you are!

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I will tell thee wonders.

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.ab: With that face?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I love thee.

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.ab: So I heard you say.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: And so, farewell.

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.ab: Fair weather after you!

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: Come, Jaquenetta, away!

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Villain, thou shalt fast for thy offences ere thou be
pardoned.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Well, sir, I hope, when I do it, I shall do it on a
full stomach.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Thou shalt be heavily punished.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: I am more bound to you than your fellows, for they are
but lightly rewarded.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Take away this villain; shut him up.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Come, you transgressing slave; away!

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Let me not be pent up, sir: I will fast, being loose.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: No, sir; that were fast and loose: thou shalt to
prison.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Well, if ever I do see the merry days of desolation
that I have seen, some shall see.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: What shall some see?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Nay, nothing, Master Moth, but what they look
upon. It is not for prisoners to be too silent
in their words; and therefore I will say nothing:
I thank God I have as little patience as another man;
and therefore I can be quiet.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I do affect the very ground, which is base, where
her shoe, which is baser, guided by her foot,
which is basest, doth tread. I shall be forsworn,
which is a great argument of falsehood, if I
love. And how can that be true love which is
falsely attempted? Love is a familiar; Love is
a devil: there is no evil angel but Love. Yet
was Samson so tempted, and he had an excellent
strength; yet was Solomon so seduced, and he had
a very good wit. Cupid's butt-shaft is too hard
for Hercules' club; and therefore too much odds
for a Spaniard's rapier. The first and second
cause will not serve my turn; the passado he
respects not, the duello he regards not: his
disgrace is to be called boy; but his glory is
to subdue men. Adieu, valour! rust, rapier! be
still, drum! for your manager is in love; yea,
he loveth. Assist me, some extemporal god of
rhyme, for I am sure I shall turn sonnet. Devise, wit;
write, pen; for I am for whole volumes in folio.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter the Princess of France, ROSALINE, MARIA, KATHARINE, BOYET, Lords, and other Attendants.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Now, madam, summon up your dearest spirits:
Consider who the king your father sends,
To whom he sends, and what's his embassy:
Yourself, held precious in the world's esteem,
To parley with the sole inheritor
Of all perfections that a man may owe,
Matchless Navarre; the plea of no less weight
Than Aquitaine, a dowry for a queen.
Be now as prodigal of all dear grace
As Nature was in making graces dear
When she did starve the general world beside
And prodigally gave them all to you.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Good Lord Boyet, my beauty, though but mean,
Needs not the painted flourish of your praise:
Beauty is bought by judgement of the eye,
Not uttered by base sale of chapmen's tongues:
I am less proud to hear you tell my worth
Than you much willing to be counted wise
In spending your wit in the praise of mine.
But now to task the tasker: good Boyet,
You are not ignorant, all-telling fame
Doth noise abroad, Navarre hath made a vow,
Till painful study shall outwear three years,
No woman may approach his silent court:
Therefore to's seemeth it a needful course,
Before we enter his forbidden gates,
To know his pleasure; and in that behalf,
Bold of your worthiness, we single you
As our best-moving fair solicitor.
Tell him, the daughter of the King of France,
On serious business, craving quick dispatch,
Importunes personal conference with his grace:
Haste, signify so much; while we attend,
Like humble-visaged suitors, his high will.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Proud of employment, willingly I go.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: All pride is willing pride, and yours is so. Exit Boyet.
Who are the votaries, my loving lords,
That are vow-fellows with this virtuous duke?

sp.speaker: Lords
sp.l: Lord Longaville is one.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Know you the man?

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: I know him, madam: at a marriage-feast,
Between Lord Perigort and the beauteous heir
Of Jaques Falconbridge, solemnized
In Normandy, saw I this Longaville:
A man of sovereign parts, peerless esteemed;
Well fitted in arts, glorious in arms:
Nothing becomes him ill that he would well.
The only soil of his fair virtue's gloss,
If virtue's gloss will stain with any soil,
Is a sharp wit matched with too blunt a will;
Whose edge hath power to cut, whose will still wills
It should none spare that come within his power.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Some merry mocking lord, belike; is't so?

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: They say so most that most his humours know.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Such short-lived wits do wither as they grow.
Who are the rest?

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: The young Dumaine; a well-accomplished youth,
Of all that virtue love for virtue loved:
Most power to do most harm, least knowing ill;
For he hath wit to make an ill shape good,
And shape to win grace though he had no wit.
I saw him at the Duke Alencon's once;
And much too little of that good I saw
Is my report to his great worthiness.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Another of these students at that time
Was there with him, if I have heard a truth.
Berowne they call him; but a merrier man,
Within the limit of becoming mirth,
I never spent an hour's talk withal:
His eye begets occasion for his wit;
For every object that the one doth catch
The other turns to a mirth-moving jest,
Which his fair tongue, conceit's expositor,
Delivers in such apt and gracious words
That aged ears play truant at his tales
And younger hearings are quite ravished;
So sweet and voluble is his discourse.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: God bless my ladies! are they all in love,
That every one her own hath garnished
With such bedecking ornaments of praise?

sp.speaker: Lords
sp.l: Here comes Boyet. Re-enter BOYET.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Now, what admittance, lord?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Navarre had notice of your fair approach;
And he and his competitors in oath
Were all addressed to meet you, gentle lady,
Before I came. Marry, thus much I have learnt:
He rather means to lodge you in the field,
Like one that comes here to besiege his court,
Than seek a dispensation for his oath,
To let you enter his unpeopled house.
Here comes Navarre. Enter KING, LONGAVILLE, Dumaine, Berowne, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Fair princess, welcome to the court of Navarre.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.ab: “Fair” I give you back again; and “welcome” I
have not yet: the roof of this court is too high
to be yours; and welcome to the wide fields too base
to be mine.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: You shall be welcome, madam, to my court.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: I will be welcome, then: conduct me thither.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Hear me, dear lady; I have sworn an oath.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Our Lady help my lord! he'll be forsworn.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Not for the world, fair madam, by my will.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Why, will shall break it; will and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Your ladyship is ignorant what it is.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Were my lord so, his ignorance were wise,
Where now his knowledge must prove ignorance.
I hear your grace hath sworn out housekeeping:
'Tis deadly sin to keep that oath, my lord,
And sin to break it.
But pardon me, I am too sudden bold:
To teach a teacher ill beseemeth me.
Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my coming,
And suddenly resolve me in my suit.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Madam, I will, if suddenly I may.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: You will the sooner, that I were away;
For you'll prove perjured if you make me stay.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: I know you did.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: How needless was it then
To ask the question!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: You must not be so quick.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: 'Tis 'long of you that spur me with such questions.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Your wit's too hot, it speeds too fast, 'twill tire.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Not till it leave the rider in the mire.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: What time o' day?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: The hour that fools should ask.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Now fair befall your mask!

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Fair fall the face it covers!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: And send you many lovers!

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Amen, so you be none.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Nay, then will I be gone.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Madam, your father here doth intimate
The payment of a hundred thousand crowns;
Being but the one half of an entire sum
Disbursed by my father in his wars.
But say that he or we, as neither have,
Received that sum, yet there remains unpaid
A hundred thousand more; in surety of the which,
One part of Aquitaine is bound to us,
Although not valued to the money's worth.
If then the king your father will restore
But that one half which is unsatisfied,
We will give up our right in Aquitaine,
And hold fair friendship with his majesty.
But that, it seems, he little purposeth,
For here he doth demand to have repaid
A hundred thousand crowns; and not demands,
On payment of a hundred thousand crowns,
To have his title live in Aquitaine;
Which we much rather had depart withal
And have the money by our father lent
Than Aquitaine so gelded as it is.
Dear princess, were not his requests so far
From reason's yielding, your fair self should make
A yielding 'gainst some reason in my breast
And go well satisfied to France again.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: You do the king my father too much wrong
And wrong the reputation of your name,
In so unseeming to confess receipt
Of that which hath so faithfully been paid.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: I do protest I never heard of it;
And if you prove it, I'll repay it back
Or yield up Aquitaine.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: We arrest your word.
Boyet, you can produce acquittances
For such a sum from special officers
Of Charles his father.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Satisfy me so.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: So please your grace, the packet is not come
Where that and other specialties are bound:
To-morrow you shall have a sight of them.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: It shall suffice me: at which interview
All liberal reason I will yield unto.
Meantime receive such welcome at my hand
As honour without breach of honour may
Make tender of to thy true worthiness:
You may not come, fair princess, within my gates;
But here without you shall be so received
As you shall deem yourself lodged in my heart,
Though so denied fair harbour in my house.
Your own good thoughts excuse me, and farewell:
To-morrow shall we visit you again.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Sweet health and fair desires consort your grace!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Thy own wish wish I thee in every place! Exit.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Lady, I will commend you to mine own heart.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.ab: Pray you, do my commendations; I would be glad to see
it.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: I would you heard it groan.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.ab: Is the fool sick?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Sick at the heart.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Alack, let it blood.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Would that do it good?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: My physic says “ay.”

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Will you prick't with your eye?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: No point, with my knife.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Now, God save thy life!

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: And yours from long living!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: I cannot stay thanksgiving. Retiring.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Sir, I pray you, a word: what lady is that same?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: The heir of Alencon, Katharine her name.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: A gallant lady. Monsieur, fare you well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: I beseech you a word: what is she in the white?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: A woman sometimes, an you saw her in the light.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Perchance light in the light. I desire her name.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: She hath but one for herself; to desire that were a shame.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Pray you, sir, whose daughter?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Her mother's, I have heard.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: God's blessing on your beard!

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Good sir, be not offended. She is an heir of Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Nay, my choler is ended. She is a most sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Not unlike, sir, that may be. Exit Long.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: What's her name in the cap?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Rosaline, by good hap.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Is she wedded or no?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: To her will, sir, or so.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: O, you are welcome, sir: adieu.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Farewell to me, sir, and welcome to you. Exit Berowne.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: That last is Berowne, the merry madcap lord:
Not a word with him but a jest.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: And every jest but a word.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: It was well done of you to take him at his word.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: I was as willing to grapple as he was to board.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: Two hot sheeps, marry.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: And wherefore not ships?
No sheep, sweet lamb, unless we feed on your lips.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: You sheep, and I pasture: shall that finish the jest?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: So you grant pasture for me. Offering to kiss her.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: Not so, gentle beast:
My lips are no common, though several they be.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Belonging to whom?

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: To my fortunes and me.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Good wits will be jangling; but, gentles, agree:
This civil war of wits were much better used
On Navarre and his book-men; for here 'tis abused.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: If my observation, which very seldom lies,
By the heart's still rhetoric disclosed with eyes,
Deceive me not now, Navarre is infected.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: With what?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: With that which we lovers entitle affected.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Why, all his behaviours did make their retire
To the court of his eye, peeping thorough desire:
His heart, like an agate, with your print impressed,
Proud with his form, in his eye pride expressed:
His tongue, all impatient to speak and not see,
Did stumble with haste in his eyesight to be;
All senses to that sense did make their repair,
To feel only looking on fairest of fair:
Methought all his senses were locked in his eye,
As jewels in crystal for some prince to buy;
Who, tendering their own worth from where they were glassed,
Did point you to buy them, along as you passed:
His face's own margent did quote such amazes
That all eyes saw his eyes enchanted with gazes.
I'll give you Aquitaine and all that is his,
An you give him for my sake but one loving kiss.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Come to our pavilion: Boyet is disposed.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: But to speak that in words which his eye hath disclosed.
I only have made a mouth of his eye,
By adding a tongue which I know will not lie.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: Thou art an old love-monger and speakest skilfully.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: He is Cupid's grandfather and learns news of him.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Then was Venus like her mother, for her father is but grim.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Do you hear, my mad wenches?

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: What then, do you see?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Ay, our way to be gone.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: You are too hard for me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Warble, child; make passionate my sense of hearing.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Concolinel.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Sweet air! Go, tenderness of years; take this
key, give enlargement to the swain, bring him
festinately hither: I must employ him in a letter to
my love.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Master, will you win your love with a French brawl?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: How meanest thou? brawling in French?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: No, my complete master: but to jig off a tune at
the tongue's end, canary to it with your feet.
humour it with turning up your eyelids, sigh a
note and sing a note, sometime through the throat,
as if you swallowed love with singing love,
sometime through the nose, as if you snuffed up
love by smelling love; with your hat penthouse-like
o'er the shop of your eyes; with your arms crossed
on your thin-belly doublet like a rabbit on a
spit; or your hands in your pocket like a man
after the old painting; and keep not too long in
one tune, but a snip and away. These are complements,
these are humours; these betray nice wenches,
that would be betrayed without these; and make
them men of note — do you note? — men that most are
affected to these.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: How hast thou purchased this experience?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: By my penny of observation.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: But O, — but O, —

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: “The hobby-horse is forgot.”

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Call'st thou my love “hobby-horse”?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: No, master; the hobby-horse is but a colt, and
your love perhaps a hackney. But have you forgot your
love?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Almost I had.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Negligent student! learn her by heart.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: By heart and in heart, boy.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: And out of heart, master: all those three I will
prove.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: What wilt thou prove?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: A man, if I live; and this, by, in, and without,
upon the instant: by heart you love her, because
your heart cannot come by her; in heart you love
her, because your heart is in love with her; and
out of heart you love her, being out of heart that you
cannot enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I am all these three.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: And three times as much more, and yet nothing at all.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Fetch hither the swain: he must carry me a letter.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: A message well sympathized; a horse to be ambassador
for an ass.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Ha, ha! what sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Marry, sir, you must send the ass upon the horse, for
he is very slow-gaited. But I go.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: The way is but short: away!

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: As swift as lead, sir.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: The meaning, pretty ingenious? Is not lead a metal
heavy, dull, and slow?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: Minime, honest master; or rather, master, no.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.l: I say lead is slow.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: You are too swift, sir, to say so:
Is that lead slow which is fired from a gun?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.l: Sweet smoke of rhetoric!
He reputes me a cannon; and the bullet, that's he:
I shoot thee at the swain.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: Thump then and I flee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.l: A most acute juvenal; volable and free of grace!
By thy favour, sweet welkin, I must sigh in thy face:
Most rude melancholy, valour gives thee place.
My herald is returned. Re-enter MOTH with COSTARD.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: A wonder, master! here's a costard broken in a shin.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.l: Some enigma, some riddle: come, thy l'envoy; begin.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: No egma, no riddle, no l'envoy; no salve in the
mail, sir: O, sir, plantain, a plain plantain!
no l'envoy; no l'envoy; no salve, sir, but a plantain!

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: By virtue, thou enforcest laughter; thy silly
thought my spleen; the heaving of my lungs provokes
me to ridiculous smiling. O, pardon me, my stars!
Doth the inconsiderate take salve for l'envoy, and the
word l'envoy for a salve?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: Do the wise think them other? is not l'envoy a salve?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.l: No, page: it is an epilogue or discourse, to make plain
Some obscure precedence that hath tofore been sain.
I will example it:

lg.l: The fox, the ape and the humble-bee,
Were still at odds, being but three.

sp.ab: There's the moral. Now the l'envoy.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: I will add the l'envoy. Say the moral again.

lg.l: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee,
Were still at odds, being but three.

sp.speaker: Moth

lg.l: Until the goose came out of door,
And stayed the odds by adding four.

sp.ab: Now will I begin your moral, and do you follow with my
l'envoy.

lg.l: The fox, the ape and the humble-bee,
Were still at odds, being but three.
Until the goose came out of door,
Staying the odds by adding four.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: A good l'envoy, ending in the goose: would you desire
more?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: The boy hath sold him a bargain, a goose, that's flat.
Sir, your pennyworth is good, an your goose be fat.
To sell a bargain well is as cunning as fast and loose:
Let me see; a fat l'envoy; ay, that's a fat goose.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.l: Come hither, come hither. How did this argument begin?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: By saying that a costard was broken in a shin.
Then called you for the l'envoy.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: True, and I for a plantain: thus came your argument in;
Then the boy's fat l'envoy, the goose that you bought;
And he ended the market.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: But tell me; how was there a costard broken in a shin?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: I will tell you sensibly.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Thou hast no feeling of it, Moth: I will speak that
l'envoy:
sp.l: I Costard, running out, that was safely within,
Fell over the threshold, and broke my shin.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: We will talk no more of this matter.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Till there be more matter in the shin.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Sirrah Costard, I will enfranchise thee.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: O, marry me to one Frances: I smell some l'envoy, some
goose, in this.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: By my sweet soul, I mean setting thee at liberty,
enfreedoming thy person: thou wert immured,
restrained, captivated, bound.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: True, true; and now you will be my purgation and let
me loose.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I give thee thy liberty, set thee from durance;
and, in lieu thereof, impose on thee nothing but
this: bear this significant
to the country maid Jaquenetta: there is
remuneration; for the best ward of mine honour is
rewarding my dependents. Moth, follow.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Like the sequel, I. Signior Costard, adieu.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: My sweet ounce of man's flesh! my incony Jew!
Now will I look to his remuneration. Remuneration!
O, that's the Latin word for three farthings:
three farthings — remuneration. — “What's the price
of this inkle?” — “One penny.” — “No, I'll give you
a remuneration:” why, it carries it. Remuneration!
why, it is a fairer name than French crown. I will
never buy and sell out of this word.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: O, my good knave Costard! exceedingly well met.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Pray you, sir, how much carnation ribbon may a man buy
for a remuneration?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: O what is a remuneration?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Marry, sir, halfpenny farthing.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: O, why then, three-farthing worth of silk.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: I thank your worship: God be wi' you!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: O stay, slave; I must employ thee:
As thou wilt win my favour, good my knave,
Do one thing for me that I shall entreat.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: When would you have it done, sir?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: O, this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Well, I will do it, sir: fare you well.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: O, thou knowest not what it is.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: I shall know, sir, when I have done it.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Why, villain, thou must know first.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: I will come to your worship to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: It must be done this afternoon.
Hark, slave, it is but this:
sp.l: The princess comes to hunt here in the park,
And in her train there is a gentle lady;
When tongues speak sweetly, then they name her name,
And Rosaline they call her: ask for her;
And to her white hand see thou do commend
This sealed-up counsel. There's thy guerdon; go. Giving him a shilling.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Gardon, O sweet gardon! better than remuneration,
aleven-pence-farthing better: most sweet gardon! I
will do it, sir, in print. Gardon! Remuneration!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: O, and I, forsooth, in love! I, that
have been love's whip;
A very beadle to a humorous sigh;
A critic, nay, a night-watch constable;
A domineering pedant o'er the boy;
Than whom no mortal so magnificent!
This wimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy;
This senior-junior, giant-dwarf, Dan Cupid;
Regent of love-rhymes, lord of folded arms,
The anointed sovereign of sighs and groans,
Liege of all loiterers and malcontents,
Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces,
Sole imperator and great general
Of trotting “paritors: — O my little heart: —
And I to be a corporal of his field,
And wear his colours like a tumbler's hoop!
What! I love! I sue! I seek a wife!
A woman, that is like a German clock,
Still a-repairing, ever out of frame,
And never going aright. being a watch,
But being watched that it may still go right!
Nay, to be perjured, which is worst of all;
And, among three, to love the worst of all;
A whitely wanton with a velvet brow,
With two pitch-balls stuck in her face for eyes;
Ay, and, by heaven, one that will do the deed
Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard:
And I to sigh for her! to watch for her!
To pray for her! Go to; it is a plague
That Cupid will impose for my neglect
Of his almighty dreadful little might.
Well, I will love, write, sigh, pray, sue, groan:
Some men must love my lady and some Joan. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter the Princess, and her train, a Forester, BOYET, ROSALINE, MARIA, and KATHARINE.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Was that the king, that spurred his horse so hard
Against the steep-up rising of the hill?

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.l: I know not; but I think it was not he.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Whoe'er 'a was, 'a showed a mounting mind.
Well, lords, to-day we shall have our dispatch:
On Saturday we will return to France.
Then, forester, my friend, where is the bush
That we must stand and play the murderer in?

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.l: Hereby, upon the edge of yonder coppice;
A stand where you may make the fairest shoot.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: I thank my beauty, I am fair that shoot,
And thereupon thou speak'st the fairest shoot.

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.l: Pardon me, madam, for I meant not so.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: What, what? first praise me and again say no?
O short-lived pride! Not fair? alack for woe!

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.l: Yes, madam, fair.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Nay, never paint me now:
Where fair is not, praise cannot mend the brow.
Here, good my glass, take this for telling true:
Fair payment for foul words is more than due.

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.l: Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: See, see, my beauty will be saved by merit!
O heresy in fair, fit for these days!
A giving hand, though foul, shall have fair praise.
But come, the bow: now mercy goes to kill,
And shooting well is then accounted ill.
Thus will I save my credit in the shoot:
Not wounding, pity would not let me do't:
If wounding, then it was to show my skill,
That more for praise than purpose meant to kill.
And out of question so it is sometimes,
Glory grows guilty of detested crimes,
When, for fame's sake, for praise, an outward part,
We bend to that the working of the heart;
As I for praise alone now seek to spill
The poor deer's blood, that my heart means no ill.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Do not curst wives hold that self-sovereignty
Only for praise sake, when they strive to be
Lords o'er their lords?

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Only for praise: and praise we may afford
To any lady that subdues a lord.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Here comes a member of the commonwealth. Enter COSTARD.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: God dig-you-den all! Pray you, which is the head lady?

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.ab: Thou shalt know her, fellow, by the rest that have no
heads.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Which is the greatest lady, the highest?

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.ab: The thickest and the tallest.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: The thickest and the tallest! it is so; truth is truth.
An your waist, mistress, were as slender as my wit,
One a' these maids' girdles for your waist should be fit.
Are not you the chief woman? you are the thickest here.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: What's your will, sir? what's your will?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: I have a letter from Monsieur Berowne to one Lady Rosaline.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: O, thy letter, thy letter! he's a good friend of mine:
Stand aside, good bearer. Boyet, you can carve;
Break up this capon.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: I am bound to serve.
This letter is mistook, it importeth none here;
It is writ to Jaquenetta.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: We will read it, I swear.
Break the neck of the wax, and every one give ear.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.ab: “By heaven, that thou art fair, is most infallible;
true, that thou art beauteous; truth itself, that
thou art lovely. More fairer than fair, beautiful
than beauteous, truer than truth itself, have
commiseration on thy heroical vassal! The
magnanimous and most illustrate king Cophetua
set eye upon the pernicious and indubitate beggar
Zenelophon; and he it was that might rightly say,
Veni, vidi, vici; which to annothanize in the
vulgar, — O base and obscure vulgar! — videlicet,
He came, saw, and overcame: he came, one; saw
two; overcame, three. Who came? the king: why
did he come? to see: why did he see? to overcome:
to whom come he? to the beggar: what saw he? the
beggar: who overcame he? the beggar. The conclusion
is victory: on whose side? the king's. The captive
is enriched: on whose side? the beggar's. The
catastrophe is a nuptial: on whose side? the
king's: no, on both in one, or one in both. I am
the king; for so stands the comparison: thou the
beggar; for so witnesseth thy lowliness. Shall
I command thy love? I may: shall I enforce thy
love? I could: shall I entreat thy love? I will.
What shalt thou exchange for rags? robes; for
titles? titles; for thyself? me. Thus, expecting
thy reply, I profane my lips on thy foot, my eyes
on thy picture, and my heart on thy every part.
Thine, in the dearest design of industry, DON ADRIANO
DE ARMADO.”
sp.l: Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar
'Gainst thee, thou lamb, that standest as his prey.
Submissive fall his princely feet before,
And he from forage will incline to play:
But if thou strive, poor soul, what art thou then?
Food for his rage, repasture for his den.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: What plume of feathers is he that indited this letter?
What vane? what weathercock? did you ever hear better?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: I am much deceived but I remember the style.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Else your memory is bad, going o'er it erewhile.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: This Armado is a Spaniard, that keeps here in court;
A phantasime, a Monarcho, and one that makes sport
To the prince and his bookmates.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Thou fellow, a word:
Who gave thee this letter?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: I told you; my lord.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: To whom shouldst thou give it?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: From my lord to my lady.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: From which lord to which lady?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: From my lord Berowne, a good master of mine,
To a lady of France that he called Rosaline.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come, lords, away. To Ros.
Here, sweet, put up this; 'twill be thine another day. Exeunt Princess and train.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Who is the shooter? who is the shooter?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Shall I teach you to know?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Ay, my continent of beauty.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Why, she that bears the bow.
Finely put off!

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: My lady goes to kill horns; but, if thou marry,
Hang me by the neck, if horns that year miscarry.
Finely put on!

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Well, then, I am the shooter.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: And who is your deer?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: If we choose by the horns, yourself come not near.
Finely put on, indeed!

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: You still wrangle with her, Boyet, and she strikes at the brow.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: But she herself is hit lower: have I hit her now?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.ab: Shall I come upon thee with an old saying, that
was a man when King Pepin of France was a little boy,
as touching the hit it?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.ab: So I may answer thee with one as old, that was
a woman when Queen Guinover of Britain was a little
wench, as touching the hit it.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Thou canst not hit it, hit it, hit it,
Thou canst not hit it, my good man.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: An I cannot, cannot, cannot,
An I cannot, another can.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: By my troth, most pleasant: how both did fit it!

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: A mark marvellous well shot, for they both did hit it.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: A mark! O, mark but that mark! A mark, says my lady!
Let the mark have a prick in't, to mete at, if it may be.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: Wide a' the bow-hand! i' faith, your hand is out.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: Indeed, 'a must shoot nearer, or he'll ne'er hit the clout.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: An if my hand be out, then belike your hand is in.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: Then will she get the upshoot by cleaving the pin.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: Come, come, you talk greasily; your lips grow foul.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: She's too hard for you at pricks, sir: challenge her to bowl.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: I fear too much rubbing. Good night, my good owl. Exeunt Boyet and Maria.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: By my soul, a swain! a most simple clown!
Lord, Lord, how the ladies and I have put him down!
O' my troth, most sweet jests! most incony vulgar wit!
When it comes so smoothly off, so obscenely, as it were, so fit.
Armado a' th' one side, — O, a most dainty man!
To see him walk before a lady and to bear her fan!
To see him kiss his hand! and how most sweetly 'a will swear!
And his page a' t'other side, that handful of wit!
Ah, heavens, it is a most pathetical nit!
Sola, sola! Shout within. Exit Costard, running.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter HOLOFERNES, SIR NATHANIEL, and DULL.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Very reverend sport, truly; and done in the testimony
of a good conscience.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: The deer was, as you know, sanguis, in blood;
ripe as the pomewater, who now hangeth like a
jewel in the ear of caelo, the sky, the welkin,
the heaven; and anon falleth like a crab on the face
of terra, the soil, the land, the earth.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Truly, Master Holofernes, the epithets are sweetly
varied, like a scholar at the least: but, sir, I
assure ye, it was a buck of the first head.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Sir Nathaniel, haud credo.

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: 'Twas not a haud credo; 'twas a pricket.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Most barbarous intimation! yet a kind of insinuation,
as it were, in via, in way, of explication;
facere, as it were, replication, or rather,
ostentare, to show, as it were, his inclination,
after his undressed, unpolished, uneducated,
unpruned, untrained, or rather, unlettered, or
ratherest, unconfirmed fashion, to insert again my
haud credo for a deer.

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: I said the deer was not a haud credo; 'twas a pricket.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.l: Twice sod simplicity, bis coctus!
O thou monster Ignorance, how deformed dost thou look!

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.l: Sir, he hath never fed of the dainties that are bred in a book;
sp.ab: He hath not eat paper, as it were; he hath not
drunk ink: his intellect is not replenished; he
is only an animal, only sensible in the duller parts:

lg.l: And such barren plants are set before us, that we thankful should be,
Which we of taste and feeling are, for those parts that do fructify in us more than he.
For as it would ill become me to be vain, indiscreet, or a fool,
So were there a patch set on learning, to see him in a school:
But omne bene, say I; being of an old father's mind,
Many can brook the weather that love not the wind.

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.l: You two are book-men: can you tell me by your wit
What was a month old at Cain's birth, that's not five weeks old as yet?

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.l: Dictynna, goodman Dull; Dictynna, goodman Dull.

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.l: What is Dictynna?

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.l: A title to Phoebe, to Luna, to the moon.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.l: The moon was a month old when Adam was no more.
And raught not to five weeks when he came to five-score.
sp.ab: The allusion holds in the exchange.

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: 'Tis true indeed: the collusion holds in the exchange.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: God comfort thy capacity! I say, the allusion holds in
the exchange.

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: And I say, the pollution holds in the exchange;
for the moon is never but a month old: and I say
beside that, 'twas a pricket that the princess killed.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Sir Nathaniel, will you hear an extemporal epitaph
on the death of the deer? And, to humour the
ignorant, call I the deer the princess killed a
pricket.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Perge, good Master Holofernes, perge; so it shall
please you to abrogate scurrility.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.l: I will something affect the letter, for it argues facility.
The preyful princess pierced and pricked a pretty pleasing pricket;
Some say a sore; but not a sore, till now made sore with shooting.
The dogs did yell; put L to sore, then sorel jumps from thicket;
Or pricket sore, or else sorel; the people fall a-hooting.
If sore be sore, then L to sore makes fifty sores o' sorel.
Of one sore I an hundred make by adding but one more L.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: A rare talent!

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: If a talent be a claw, look how he claws him with a
talent.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: This is a gift that I have, simple, simple; a
foolish extravagant spirit, full of forms, figures,
shapes, objects, ideas, apprehensions, motions,
revolutions: these are begot in the ventricle of
memory, nourished in the womb of pia mater, and
delivered upon the mellowing of occasion. But
the gift is good in those in whom it is acute, and I
am thankful for it.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Sir, I praise the Lord for you: and so may my
parishioners; for their sons are well tutored by
you, and their daughters profit very greatly
under you: you are a good member of the commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Mehercle, if their sons be ingenious, they shall
want no instruction; if their daughters be capable,
I will put it to them: but vir sapit qui pauca
loquitur; a soul feminine saluteth us.

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.ab: God give you good morrow, master Person.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Master Person, quasi pers-one. An if one should be
pierced, which is the one?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Marry, master schoolmaster, he that is likest to a
hogshead.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Of piercing a hogshead! a good lustre of conceit
in a turf of earth; fire enough for a flint, pearl
enough for a swine: 'tis pretty; it is well.

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.ab: Good master Person, be so good as read me this
letter: it was given me by Costard, and sent me from
Don Armado: I beseech you, read it.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Facile, precor gelida quando pecus omne sub umbra
Ruminat, — and so forth. Ah, good old Mantuan! I may
speak of thee as the traveller doth of Venice;
sp.l: Venetia, Venetia,
Chi non ti vede, qui non ti pretia.
sp.ab: Old Mantuan, old Mantuan! who understandeth thee
not, loves thee not. Ut, re, sol, la, mi, fa.
Under pardon, sir, what are the contents? or rather,
as Horace says in his — What, my soul, verses?

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Ay, sir, and very learned.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Let me hear a staff, a stanze, a verse; lege, domine.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.l: If love make me forsworn, how shall I swear to love?
Ah, never faith could hold, if not to beauty vowed!
Though to myself forsworn, to thee I'll faithful prove;
Those thoughts to me were oaks, to thee like osiers bowed.
Study his bias leaves and makes his book thine eyes,
Where all those pleasures live that art would comprehend:
If knowledge be the mark, to know thee shall suffice;
Well learned is that tongue that well can thee commend,
All ignorant that soul that sees thee without wonder;
Which is to me some praise that I thy parts admire:
Thy eye Jove's lightning bears, thy voice his dreadful thunder,
Which, not to anger bent, is music and sweet fire.
Celestial as thou art, O, pardon, love, this wrong,
That sings heaven's praise with such an earthly tongue.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: You find not the apostraphas, and so miss the
accent: let me supervise the canzonet. Here are
only numbers ratified; but, for the elegancy,
facility, and golden cadence of poesy, caret.
Ovidius Naso was the man: and why, indeed, Naso,
but for smelling out the odoriferous flowers of
fancy, the jerks of invention? Imitari is nothing:
so doth the hound his master, the ape his keeper,
the tired horse his rider. But, damosella virgin, was
this directed to you?

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.ab: Ay, sir, from one Monsieur Berowne, one of the strange
queen's lords.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: I will overglance the superscript: “To the
snow-white hand of the most beauteous Lady
Rosaline.” I will look again on the intellect of
the letter, for the nomination of the party
writing to the person written unto: “Your ladyship's
in all desired employment, Berowne.” Sir Nathaniel,
this Berowne is one of the votaries with the
king; and here he hath framed a letter to a
sequent of the stranger queen's, which accidentally,
or by the way of progression, hath miscarried.
Trip and go, my sweet; deliver this paper into
the royal hand of the king: it may concern much. Stay
not thy compliment; I forgive thy duty: adieu.

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.ab: Good Costard, go with me. Sir, God save your life!

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Have with thee, my girl.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Sir, you have done this in the fear of God, very
religiously; and, as a certain father saith, —

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Sir, tell not me of the father; I do fear colourable
colours. But to return to the verses: did they please
you, Sir Nathaniel?

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Marvellous well for the pen.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: I do dine to-day at the father's of a certain
pupil of mine; where, if, before repast, it shall
please you to gratify the table with a grace, I
will, on my privilege I have with the parents of
the foresaid child or pupil, undertake your ben
venuto; where I will prove those verses to be
very unlearned, neither savouring of poetry, wit, nor
invention: I beseech your society.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: And thank you too; for society, saith the text, is the
happiness of life.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: And, certes, the text most infallibly concludes
it.
Sir, I do invite you too; you shall not say me
nay: pauca verba. Away! the gentles are at their game,
and we will to our recreation.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: The king he is hunting the deer; I am coursing
myself: they have pitched a toil; I am toiling
in a pitch, — pitch that defiles: defile! a foul
word. Well, set thee down, sorrow! for so they
say the fool said, and so say I, and I the fool:
well proved, wit! By the Lord, this love is as
mad as Ajax: it kills sheep; it kills me, I a
sheep: well proved again a' my side! I will not
love: if I do, hang me; i' faith, I will not. O,
but her eye, — by this light, but for her eye, I
would not love her; yes, for her two eyes. Well,
I do nothing in the world but lie, and lie in my
throat. By heaven, I do love: and it hath taught
me to rhyme and to be melancholy; and here is
part of my rhyme, and here my melancholy. Well,
she hath one a' my sonnets already: the clown
bore it, the fool sent it, and the lady hath it:
sweet clown, sweeter fool, sweetest lady! By the
world, I would not care a pin, if the other three
were in. Here comes one with a paper: God give him
grace to groan!
sp.stage: Enter the King, with a paper.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: Ay, me!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Shot, by heaven! Proceed, sweet Cupid: thou hast
thumped him with thy bird-bolt under the left pap. In
faith, secrets!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: So sweet a kiss the golden sun gives not
To those fresh morning drops upon the rose,
As thy eye-beams, when their fresh rays have smote
The night of dew that on my cheeks down flows:
Nor shines the silver moon one half so bright
Through the transparent bosom of the deep,
As doth thy face through tears of mine give light;
Thou shinest in every tear that I do weep:
No drop but as a coach doth carry thee;
So ridest thou triumphing in my woe,
Do but behold the tears that swell in me,
And they thy glory through my grief will show:
But do not love thyself; then thou wilt keep
My tears for glasses, and still make me weep.
O queen of queens! how far dost thou excel,
No thought can think, nor tongue of mortal tell.
How shall she know my griefs? I'll drop the paper:
Sweet leaves, shade folly. Who is he comes here? Steps aside
What, Longaville! and reading! listen, ear.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Now, in thy likeness, one more fool appear! Enter LONGAVILLE, with a paper.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Ay me, I am forsworn!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Why, he comes in like a perjure, wearing papers.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: In love, I hope: sweet fellowship in shame!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: One drunkard loves another of the name.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Am I the first that have been perjured so?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: I could put thee in comfort. Not by two that I know:
Thou makest the triumphery, the corner-cap of society,
The shape of Love's Tyburn that hangs up simplicity.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: I fear these stubborn lines lack power to move.
O sweet Maria, empress of my love!
These numbers will I tear, and write in prose.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: O, rhymes are guards on wanton Cupid's hose:
Disfigure not his shop.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: This same shall go. Reads.
Did not the heavenly rhetoric of thine eye,
'Gainst whom the world cannot hold argument,
Persuade my heart to this false perjury?
Vows for thee broke deserve not punishment.
A woman I forswore; but I will prove,
Thou being a goddess, I forswore not thee:
My vow was earthly, thou a heavenly love;
Thy grace being gained cures all disgrace in me.
Vows are but breath, and breath a vapour is:
Then thou, fair sun, which on my earth dost shine,
Exhalest this vapour-vow; in thee it is:
If broken then, it is no fault of mine:
If by me broke, what fool is not so wise
To lose an oath to win a paradise?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: This is the liver-vein, which makes flesh a deity,
A green goose a goddess: pure, pure idolatry.
God amend us, God amend! we are much out a' the way.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: By whom shall I send this? — Company! stay. Steps aside.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: All hid, all hid; an old infant play.
Like a demigod here sit I in the sky,
And wretched fools' secrets heedfully o'ereye.
More sacks to the mill! O heavens, I have my wish! Enter Dumaine, with a paper.
Dumaine transformed! four woodcocks in a dish!

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: O most divine Kate!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: O most profane coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: By heaven, the wonder in a mortal eye!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: By earth, she is not, corporal, there you lie.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Her amber hairs for foul hath amber quoted.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: An amber-coloured raven was well noted.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: As upright as the cedar.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Stoop, I say;
Her shoulder is with child.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: As fair as day.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Ay, as some days; but then no sun must shine.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: O that I had my wish!

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: And I had mine!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: And mine too, good Lord!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Amen, so I had mine: is not that a good word?

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: I would forget her; but a fever she
Reigns in my blood and will remembered be.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: A fever in your blood! why, then incision
Would let her out in saucers: sweet misprision!

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Once more I'll read the ode that I have writ.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Once more I'll mark how love can vary wit.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: On a day — alack the day! —
Love, whose month is ever May,
Spied a blossom passing fair
Playing in the wanton air:
Through the velvet leaves the wind,
All unseen, can passage find;
That the lover, sick to death,
Wished himself the heaven's breath.
Air, quoth he, thy cheeks may blow;
Air, would I might triumph so!
But, alack, my hand is sworn
Ne'er to pluck thee from thy thorn;
Vow, alack, for youth unmeet,
Youth so apt to pluck a sweet!
Do not call it sin in me,
That I am forsworn for thee;
Thou for whom Jove would swear
Juno but an Ethiope were;
And deny himself for Jove,
Turning mortal for thy love.
This will I send and something else more plain,
That shall express my true love's fasting pain.
O, would the king, Berowne, and Longaville,
Were lovers too! Ill, to example ill,
Would from my forehead wipe a perjured note;
For none offend where all alike do dote.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Dumaine, thy love is far from charity,
That in love's grief desirest society:
You may look pale, but I should blush, I know,
To be o'erheard and taken napping so.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Come, sir, you blush; as his your case is such;
You chide at him, offending twice as much;
You do not love Maria; Longaville
Did never sonnet for her sake compile,
Nor never lay his wreathed arms athwart
His loving bosom to keep down his heart.
I have been closely shrouded in this bush
And marked you both and for you both did blush:
I heard your guilty rhymes, observed your fashion,
Saw sighs reek from you, noted well your passion:
Ay me! says one; O Jove! the other cries;
One, her hairs were gold, crystal the other's eyes: To Long.
You would for paradise break faith and troth; To Dum.
And Jove, for your love, would infringe an oath.
What will Berowne say when that he shall hear
Faith infringed, which such zeal did swear?
How will he scorn! how will he spend his wit!
How will he triumph, leap and laugh at it!
For all the wealth that ever I did see,
I would not have him know so much by me.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Now step I forth to whip hypocrisy. Advancing.
Ah, good my liege, I pray thee, pardon me!
Good heart, what grace hast thou, thus to reprove
These worms for loving, that art most in love?
Your eyes do make no coaches; in your tears
There is no certain princess that appears;
You'll not be perjured, 'tis a hateful thing;
Tush, none but minstrels like of sonneting!
But are you not ashamed? nay, are you not,
All three of you, to be thus much o'ershot?
You found his mote; the king your mote did see;
But I a beam do find in each of three.
O, what a scene of foolery have I seen,
Of sighs, of groans, of sorrow and of teen!
O me, with what strict patience have I sat,
To see a king transformed to a gnat!
To see great Hercules whipping a gig,
And profound Solomon to tune a jig,
And Nestor play at push-pin with the boys,
And critic Timon laugh at idle toys!
Where lies thy grief, O, tell me, good Dumaine?
And, gentle Longaville, where lies thy pain?
And where my liege's? all about the breast:
A caudle, ho!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Too bitter is thy jest.
Are we betrayed thus to thy overview?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Not you by me, but I betrayed to you:
I, that am honest; I, that hold it sin
To break the vow I am engaged in;
I am betrayed, by keeping company
With men like you, men of inconstancy.
When shall you see me write a thing in rhyme?
Or groan for Joan? or spend a minute's time
In pruning me? When shall you hear that I
Will praise a hand, a foot, a face, an eye,
A gait, a state, a brow, a breast, a waist,
A leg, a limb?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Soft! whither away so fast
A true man or a thief that gallops so?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: I post from love: good lover, let me go. Enter JAQUENETTA and COSTARD.

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.l: God bless the king!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: What present hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: Some certain treason.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: What makes treason here?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: Nay, it makes nothing, sir.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: If it mar nothing neither,
The treason and you go in peace away together.

lg.l: I beseech your grace, let this letter be read:
Our person misdoubts it; 'twas treason, he said.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Berowne, read it over. Giving him the paper. Where hadst thou it?

sp.speaker: Jaquenetta
sp.l: Of Costard.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Where hadst thou it?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: Of Dun Adramadio, Dun Adramadio. Berowne tears the letter.

lg.l: How now! what is in you? why dost thou tear it?
A toy, my liege, a toy: your grace needs not fear it.
It did move him to passion, and therefore let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: It is Berowne's writing, and here is his name. Gathering up the pieces.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Ah, you whoreson loggerhead! you were born to do me shame.
Guilty, my lord, guilty! I confess, I confess.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: That you three fools lacked me fool to make up the mess:
He, he, and you, and you, my liege, and I,
Are pickpurses in love, and we deserve to die.
O, dismiss this audience, and I shall tell you more.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Now the number is even.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: True, true; we are four.
Will these turtles be gone?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Hence, sirs; away!

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: Walk aside the true folk, and let the traitors stay. Exeunt Costard and Jaquenetta.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Sweet lords, sweet lovers, O, let us embrace!
As true we are as flesh and blood can be:
The sea will ebb and flow, heaven show his face;
Young blood doth not obey an old decree:
We cannot cross the cause why we were born;
Therefore of all hands must we be forsworn.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: What, did these rent lines show some love of thine?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Did they, quoth you? Who sees the heavenly Rosaline,
That, like a rude and savage man of Ind,
At the first opening of the gorgeous east,
Bows not his vassal head and strucken blind
Kisses the base ground with obedient breast?
What peremptory eagle-sighted eye
Dares look upon the heaven of her brow,
That is not blinded by her majesty?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: What zeal, what fury hath inspired thee now?
My love, her mistress, is a gracious moon;
She an attending star, scarce seen a light.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: My eyes are then no eyes, nor I Berowne:
O, but for my love, day would turn to night!
Of all complexions the culled sovereignty
Do meet, as at a fair, in her fair cheek,
Where several worthies make one dignity,
Where nothing wants that want itself doth seek.
Lend me the flourish of all gentle tongues, —
Fie, painted rhetoric! O, she needs it not:
To things of sale a seller's praise belongs,
She passes praise; then praise too short doth blot.
A withered hermit, five-score winters worn,
Might shake off fifty, looking in her eye:
Beauty doth varnish age, as if new born,
And gives the crutch the cradle's infancy:
O, 'tis the sun that maketh all things shine.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: By heaven, thy love is black as ebony.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Is ebony like her? O wood divine!
A wife of such wood were felicity.
O, who can give an oath? where is a book?
That I may swear beauty doth beauty lack,
If that she learn not of her eye to look:
No face is fair that is not full so black.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: O paradox! Black is the badge of hell,
The hue of dungeons and the school of night;
And beauty's crest becomes the heavens well.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Devils soonest tempt, resembling spirits of light.
O, if in black my lady's brows be decked,
It mourns that painting and usurping hair
Should ravish doters with a false aspect;
And therefore is she born to make black fair.
Her favour turns the fashion of the days,
For native blood is counted painting now;
And therefore red, that would avoid dispraise,
Paints itself black, to imitate her brow.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: To look like her are chimney-sweepers black.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: And since her time are colliers counted bright.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: And Ethiopes of their sweet complexion crack.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Dark needs no candles now, for dark is light.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Your mistresses dare never come in rain,
For fear their colours should be washed away.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: 'Twere good, yours did; for, sir, to tell you plain,
I'll find a fairer face not washed to-day.
