sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: I'll prove her fair, or talk till doomsday here.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: No devil will fright thee then so much as she.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: I never knew man hold vile stuff so dear.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Look, here's thy love: my foot and her face see.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: O, if the streets were paved with thine eyes,
Her feet were much too dainty for such tread!

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: O vile! then, as she goes, what upward lies
The street should see as she walked overhead.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: But what of this? are we not all in love?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: O, nothing so sure; and thereby all forsworn.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Then leave this chat; and, good Berowne, now prove
Our loving lawful, and our faith not torn.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Ay, marry, there; some flattery for this evil.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: O, some authority how to proceed;
Some tricks, some quillets, how to cheat the devil.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Some salve for perjury.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: O, 'tis more than need.
Have at you, then, affection's men-at-arms.
Consider what you first did swear unto,
To fast, to study, and to see no woman;
Flat treason 'gainst the kingly state of youth.
Say, can you fast? your stomachs are too young;
And abstinence engenders maladies.
And where that you have vowed to study, lords,
In that each of you have forsworn his book,
Can you still dream and pore and thereon look?
For when would you, my lord, or you, or you,
Have found the ground of study's excellence
Without the beauty of a woman's face?
From women's eyes this doctrine I derive;
They are the ground, the books, the academes
From whence doth spring the true Promethean fire.
Why, universal plodding poisons up
The nimble spirits in the arteries,
As motion and long-during action tires
The sinewy vigour of the traveller.
Now, for not looking on a woman's face,
You have in that forsworn the use of eyes
And study too, the causer of your vow;
For where is any author in the world
Teaches such beauty as a woman's eye?
Learning is but an adjunct to ourself
And where we are our learning likewise is:
Then when ourselves we see in ladies' eyes,
With ourselves,
Do we not likewise see our learning there?
O, we have made a vow to study, lords,
And in that vow we have forsworn our books.
For when would you, my liege, or you, or you,
In leaden contemplation have found out
Such fiery numbers as the prompting eyes
Of beauty's tutors have enriched you with?
Other slow arts entirely keep the brain;
And therefore, finding barren practisers,
Scarce show a harvest of their heavy toil:
But love, first learned in a lady's eyes,
Lives not alone immured in the brain;
But, with the motion of all elements,
Courses as swift as thought in every power,
And gives to every power a double power,
Above their functions and their offices.
It adds a precious seeing to the eye;
A lover's eyes will gaze an eagle blind;
A lover's ear will hear the lowest sound,
When the suspicious head of theft is stopped:
Love's feeling is more soft and sensible
Than are the tender horns of cockled snails;
Love's tongue proves dainty Bacchus gross in taste:
For valour, is not Love a Hercules,
Still climbing trees in the Hesperides?
Subtle as Sphinx; as sweet and musical
As bright Apollo's lute, strung with his hair:
And when Love speaks, the voice of all the gods
Make heaven drowsy with the harmony.
Never durst poet touch a pen to write
Until his ink were tempered with Love's sighs;
O, then his lines would ravish savage ears
And plant in tyrants mild humility.
From women's eyes this doctrine I derive:
They sparkle still the right Promethean fire;
They are the books, the arts, the academes,
That show, contain and nourish all the world:
Else none at all in aught proves excellent.
Then fools you were these women to forswear,
Or keeping what is sworn, you will prove fools.
For wisdom's sake, a word that all men love,
Or for love's sake, a word that loves all men,
Or for men's sake, the authors of these women,
Or women's sake, by whom we men are men,
Let us once lose our oaths to find ourselves,
Or else we lose ourselves to keep our oaths,
It is religion to be thus forsworn,
For charity itself fulfils the law,
And who can sever love from charity?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Saint Cupid, then! and, soldiers, to the field!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Advance your standards, and upon them, lords;
Pell-mell, down with them! but be first advised,
In conflict that you get the sun of them.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Now to plain-dealing; lay these glozes by:
Shall we resolve to woo these girls of France?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: And win them too: therefore let us devise
Some entertainment for them in their tents.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: First, from the park let us conduct them thither;
Then homeward every man attach the hand
Of his fair mistress: in the afternoon
We will with some strange pastime solace them,
Such as the shortness of the time can shape;
For revels, dances, masks and merry hours
Forerun fair Love, strewing her way with flowers.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Away, away! no time shall be omitted
That will be time, and may by us be fitted.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Allons! allons! Sowed cockle reaped no corn;
And justice always whirls in equal measure:
Light wenches may prove plagues to men forsworn;
If so, our copper buys no better treasure. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter HOLOFERNES, SIR NATHANIEL, and DULL.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Satis quid sufficit.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: I praise God for you, sir: your reasons at dinner
have been sharp and sententious: pleasant without
scurrility, witty, without affection, audacious
without impudency, learned without opinion, and
strange without heresy. I did converse this
quondam day with a companion of the king's, who
is intituled, nominated or called, Don Adriano de
Armado.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Novi hominem tanquam te: his humour is lofty,
his discourse peremptory, his tongue filed, his
eye ambitious, his gait majestical, and his
general behaviour vain, ridiculous, and thrasonical.
He is too picked, too spruce, too affected, too odd,
as it were, too peregrinate, as I may call it.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: A most singular and choice epithet.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: He draweth out the thread of his verbosity finer
than the staple of his argument. I abhor such
fanatical phantasimes, such insociable and
point-devise companions; such rackers of orthography,
as to speak dout, fine, when he should say doubt;
det, when he should pronounce debt, — d, e, b, t,
not d, e, t: he clepeth a calf, cauf; half, hauf;
neighbour vocatur nebour; neigh abbreviated ne.
This is abhominable, — which he would call abbominable:
it insinuateth me of insanie: ne intelligis, domine?
to make frantic, lunatic.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Laus Deo, bene intelligo.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Bone? Bone for bene? Priscian a little scratched,
'twill serve.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Videsne quis venit?

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Video, et gaudeo.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Chirrah!

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Quare chirrah, not sirrah?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Men of peace, well encountered.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Most military sir, salutation.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: They have been at a great feast of languages, and
stolen the scraps.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: O, they have lived long on the alms-basket of
words. I marvel thy master hath not eaten thee
for a word; for thou art not so long by the head
as honorificabilitudinitatibus: thou art easier
swallowed than a flap-dragon.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Peace! the peal begins.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Monsieur, are you not lettered?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Yes, yes; he teaches boys the hornbook. What is a, b,
spelt backward, with the horn on his head?

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Ba, pueritia, with a horn added.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Ba, most silly sheep with a horn. You hear his
learning.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Quis, quis, thou consonant?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: The last of the five vowels, if you repeat them; or
the fifth, if I.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: I will repeat them, — a, e, i, —

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: The sheep: the other two concludes it, — o, u.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Now, by the salt wave of the Mediterraneum, a
sweet touch, a quick venue of wit! snip, snap, quick
and home! it rejoiceth my intellect: true wit!

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Offered by a child to an old man; which is wit-old.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: What is the figure? what is the figure?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Horns.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Thou disputes like an infant; go, whip thy gig.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Lend me your horn to make one, and I will whip
about your infamy manu cita, — a gig of a cuckold's
horn.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: An I had but one penny in the world, thou shouldst
have it to buy gingerbread: hold, there is the
very remuneration I had of thy master, thou
halfpenny purse of wit, thou pigeon-egg of
discretion. O, an the heavens were so pleased
that thou wert but my bastard, what a joyful
father wouldst thou make me! Go to; thou hast it ad
dunghill, at the fingers' ends, as they say.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: O, I smell false Latin; dunghill for unguem.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Arts-man, preambulate, we will be singuled from
the barbarous. Do you not educate youth at the
charge-house on the top of the mountain?

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Or mons, the hill.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: At your sweet pleasure, for the mountain.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: I do, sans question.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Sir, it is the king's most sweet pleasure and
affection to congratulate the princess at her
pavilion in the posteriors of this day, which the rude
multitude call the afternoon.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: The posterior of the day, most generous sir, is
liable, congruent and measurable for the afternoon:
the word is well culled, chose, sweet and apt, I do
assure you, sir, I do assure.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Sir, the king is a noble gentleman, and my
familiar, I do assure ye, very good friend: for
what is inward between us, let it pass. I do
beseech thee, remember thy courtesy; I beseech
thee, apparel thy head: and among other importunate
and most serious designs, and of great import
indeed, too, but let that pass: for I must tell
thee, it will please his grace, by the world,
sometime to lean upon my poor shoulder, and with
his royal finger, thus, dally with my excrement,
with my mustachio; but, sweet heart, let that
pass. By the world, I recount no fable: some
certain special honours it pleaseth his greatness
to impart to Armado, a soldier, a man of travel,
that hath seen the world; but let that pass. The
very all of all is, — but, sweet heart, I do implore
secrecy, — that the king would have me present the
princess, sweet chuck, with some delightful
ostentation, or show, or pageant, or antique, or
firework. Now, understanding that the curate and
your sweet self are good at such eruptions and
sudden breaking out of mirth, as it were, I have
acquainted you withal, to the end to crave your
assistance.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Sir, you shall present before her the Nine
Worthies. Sir Nathaniel, as concerning some
entertainment of time, some show in the posterior
of this day, to be rendered by our assistance,
the king's command, and this most gallant,
illustrate, and learned gentleman, before the
princess; I say none so fit as to present the Nine
Worthies.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Where will you find men worthy enough to present them?

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Joshua, yourself; myself and this gallant gentleman,
Judas Maccabaeus; this swain, because of his
great limb or joint, shall pass Pompey the Great; the
page, Hercules, —

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Pardon, sir; error: he is not quantity enough
for that Worthy's thumb: he is not so big as the end
of his club.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Shall I have audience? he shall present Hercules
in minority: his enter and exit shall be strangling a
snake; and I will have an apology for that purpose.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: An excellent device! so, if any of the audience
hiss, you may cry “Well done, Hercules! now thou
crushest the snake!” that is the way to make an
offence gracious, though few have the grace to do it.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: For the rest of the Worthies? —

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: I will play three myself.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Thrice-worthy gentleman!

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Shall I tell you a thing?

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: We attend.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: We will have, if this fadge not, an antique. I beseech
you, follow.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Via, goodman Dull! thou hast spoken no word all this
while.

sp.speaker: Dull
sp.ab: Nor understood none neither, sir.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Allons! we will employ thee.

lg.l: I'll make one in a dance, or so; or I will play
On the tabor to the Worthies, and let them dance the hay.
Most dull, honest Dull! To our sport away! Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter the Princess, KATHARINE, ROSALINE, and MARIA.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Sweet hearts, we shall be rich ere we depart,
If fairings come thus plentifully in:
A lady walled about with diamonds!
Look you what I have from the loving king.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Madam, came nothing else along with that?

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Nothing but this! yes, as much love in rhyme
As would be crammed up in a sheet of paper,
Writ a' both sides the leaf, margent and all,
That he was fain to seal on Cupid's name.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: That was the way to make his godhead wax,
For he hath been five thousand year a boy,

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: Ay, and a shrewd unhappy gallows too.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: You'll ne'er be friends with him; 'a killed your sister.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: He made her melancholy, sad, and heavy;
And so she died: had she been light, like you,
Of such a merry, nimble, stirring spirit,
She might ha' been a grandam ere she died:
And so may you; for a light heart lives long.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: What's your dark meaning, mouse, of this light word?

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: A light condition in a beauty dark.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: We need more light to find your meaning out.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: You'll mar the light by taking it in snuff;
Therefore I'll darkly end the argument.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Look, what you do, you do it still i' the dark.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: So do not you, for you are a light wench.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Indeed I weigh not you, and therefore light.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: You weigh me not? O, that's you care not for me.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Great reason; for “past cure is still past care.”

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Well bandied both; a set of wit well played.
But, Rosaline, you have a favour too:
Who sent it? and what is it?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: I would you knew:
An if my face were but as fair as yours,
My favour were as great: be witness this.
Nay, I have verses too, I thank Berowne:
The numbers true; and, were the numbering too,
I were the fairest goddess on the ground:
I am compared to twenty thousand fairs,
O, he hath drawn my picture in his letter!

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Any thing like?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Much in the letters; nothing in the praise.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Beauteous as ink; a good conclusion.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: Fair as a text B in a copy-book.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: “Ware pencils, ho! let me not die your debtor,
My red dominical, my golden letter:
O that your face were not so full of O's!

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: A pox of that jest! and I beshrew all shrows.
But, Katharine, what was sent to you from fair Dumaine?

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: Madam, this glove.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Did he not send you twain?

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: Yes, madam, and moreover
Some thousand verses of a faithful lover,
A huge translation of hypocrisy,
Vilely compiled, profound simplicity.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: This and these pearls to me sent Longaville:
The letter is too long by half a mile.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: I think no less. Dost thou not wish in heart
The chain were longer and the letter short?

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: Ay, or I would these hands might never part.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: We are wise girls to mock our lovers so.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: They are worse fools to purchase mocking so.
That same Berowne I'll torture ere I go:
O that I knew he were but in by the week!
How I would make him fawn and beg and seek
And wait the season and observe the times
And spend his prodigal wits in bootless rhymes
And shape his service wholly to my device
And make him proud to make me proud that jests!
So pair-taunt-like would I o'ersway his state
That he should be my fool and I his fate.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: None are so surely caught, when they are catched,
As wit turned fool: folly, in wisdom hatched.
Hath wisdom's warrant and the help of school
And wit's own grace to grace a learned fool.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: The blood of youth burns not with such excess
As gravity's revolt to wantonness.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: Folly in fools bears not so strong a note
As foolery in the wise, when wit doth dote;
Since all the power thereof it doth apply
To prove, by wit, worth in simplicity.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Here comes Boyet, and mirth is in his face. Enter BOYET.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: O, I am stabbed with laughter! Where's her grace?

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Thy news, Boyet?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Prepare, madam, prepare!
Arm, wenches, arm! encounters mounted are
Against your peace: Love doth approach disguised,
Armed in arguments; you'll be surprised:
Muster your wits; stand in your own defence;
Or hide your heads like cowards, and fly hence.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Saint Denis to Saint Cupid! What are they
That charge their breath against us? say, scout, say.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Under the cool shade of a sycamore
I thought to close mine eyes some half an hour;
When, lo! to interrupt my purposed rest,
Toward that shade I might behold addressed
The king and his companions: warily
I stole into a neighbour thicket by,
And overheard what you shall overhear,
That, by and by, disguised they will be here.
Their herald is a pretty knavish page,
That well by heart hath conned his embassage:
Action and accent did they teach him there;
“Thus must thou speak,” and “thus thy body bear:”
And ever and anon they made a doubt
Presence majestical would put him out;
“For,” quoth the king, “an angel shalt thou see;
Yet fear not thou, but speak audaciously.”
The boy replied, “An angel is not evil;
I should have feared her had she been a devil.”
With that, all laughed and clapped him on the shoulder,
Making the bold wag by their praises bolder:
One rubbed his elbow thus, and fleered and swore
A better speech was never spoke before;
Another, with his finger and his thumb,
Cried, “Via! we will do't, come what will come;”
The third he capered, and cried, “All goes well;”
The fourth turned on the toe, and down he fell.
With that, they all did tumble on the ground,
With such a zealous laughter, so profound,
That in this spleen ridiculous appears,
To check their folly, passion's solemn tears.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: But what, but what, come they to visit us?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: They do, they do; and are apparelled thus,
Like Muscovites or Russians, as I guess.
Their purpose is to parley, to court and dance;
And every one his love-feat will advance
Unto his several mistress, which they'll know
By favours several which they did bestow.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: And will they so? the gallants shall be tasked;
For, ladies, we will every one be masked;
And not a man of them shall have the grace,
Despite of suit, to see a lady's face.
Hold, Rosaline, this favour thou shalt wear,
And then the king will court thee for his dear;
Hold, take thou this, my sweet, and give me thine,
So shall Berowne take me for Rosaline.
And change you favours too; so shall your loves
Woo contrary, deceived by these removes.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Come on, then; wear the favours most in sight.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: But in this changing what is your intent?

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: The effect of my intent is to cross theirs:
They do it but in mockery merriment;
And mock for mock is only my intent.
Their several counsels they unbosom shall
To loves mistook, and so be mocked withal
Upon the next occasion that we meet,
With visages displayed, to talk and greet.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: But shall we dance, if they desire us to't?

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: No, to the death, we will not move a foot;
Nor to their penned speech render we no grace,
But while 'tis spoke each turn away her face.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Why, that contempt will kill the speaker's heart,
And quite divorce his memory from his part.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Therefore I do it; and I make no doubt
The rest will ne'er come in, if he be out
There's no such sport as sport by sport o'erthrown,
To make theirs ours and ours none but our own:
So shall we stay, mocking intended game,
And they, well mocked, depart away with shame. Trumpets sound within.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: The trumpet sounds: be masked; the maskers come. The Ladies mask. Enter Blackamoors with music; MOTH; the King, Berowne, LONGAVILLE, and Dumaine, in Russian habits, and masked.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: All hail, the richest beauties on the earth! —

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Beauties no richer than rich taffeta.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: A holy parcel of the fairest dames The Ladies turn their backs to him.
That ever turned their — backs — to mortal views!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Their eyes, villain, their eyes.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: That ever turned their eyes to mortal views! —
Out —

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: True; out indeed.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: Out of your favours, heavenly spirits, vouchsafe
Not to behold —

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Once to behold, rogue.

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: Once to behold with your sun-beamed eyes,
— with your sun-beamed eyes —

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: They will not answer to that epithet;
You were best call it “daughter-beamed eyes.”

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: They do not mark me, and that brings me out.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Is this your perfectness? be gone, you rogue! Exit Moth.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: What would these strangers? know their minds, Boyet:
If they do speak our language, 'tis our will
That some plain man recount their purposes:
Know what they would.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: What would you with the princess?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Nothing but peace and gentle visitation.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: What would they, say they?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Nothing but peace and gentle visitation.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Why, that they have; and bid them so be gone.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: She says, you have it, and you may be gone.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Say to her, we have measured many miles
To tread a measure with her on this grass.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: They say, that they have measured many a mile
To tread a measure with you on this grass.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: It is not so. Ask them how many inches
Is in one mile: if they have measured many,
The measure then of one is easily told.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: If to come hither you have measured miles,
And many miles, the princess bids you tell
How many inches doth fill up one mile.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Tell her, we measure them by weary steps.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: She hears herself.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: How many weary steps,
Of many weary miles you have o'ergone,
Are numbered in the travel of one mile?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: We number nothing that we spend for you:
Our duty is so rich, so infinite,
That we may do it still without accompt.
Vouchsafe to show the sunshine of your face,
That we, like savages, may worship it.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: My face is but a moon, and clouded too.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Blessed are clouds, to do as such clouds do!
Vouchsafe, bright moon, and these thy stars, to shine,
Those clouds removed, upon our watery eyne.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: O vain petitioner! beg a greater matter;
Thou now requests but moonshine in the water.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Then, in our measure do but vouchsafe one change.
Thou bid'st me beg: this begging is not strange.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Play, music, then! Nay, you must do it soon. Music plays.
Not yet! no dance! Thus change I like the moon.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Will you not dance? How come you thus estranged?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: You took the moon at full, but now she's changed.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Yet still she is the moon, and I the man.
The music plays; vouchsafe some motion to it.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Our ears vouchsafe it.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: But your legs should do it.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Since you are strangers and come here by chance,
We'll not be nice: take hands. We will not dance.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Why take we hands, then?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Only to part friends:
Curtsy, sweet hearts; and so the measure ends.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: More measure of this measure; be not nice.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: We can afford no more at such a price.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Price you yourselves: what buys your company?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Your absence only.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: That can never be.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Then cannot we be bought: and so, adieu;
Twice to your visor, and half once to you.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: If you deny to dance, let's hold more chat.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: In private, then.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: I am best pleased with that. They converse apart.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: White-handed mistress, one sweet word with thee.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Honey, and milk, and sugar; there is three.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Nay then, two treys, and if you grow so nice,
Metheglin, wort, and malmsey: well run, dice!
There's half a dozen sweets.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Seventh sweet, adieu:
Since you can cog, I'll play no more with you.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: One word in secret.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Let it not be sweet.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Thou grievest my gall.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Gall! bitter.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Therefore meet. They converse apart.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Will you vouchsafe with me to change a word?

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: Name it.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Fair lady, —

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: Say you so? Fair lord, —
Take that for your fair lady.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Please it you,
As much in private, and I'll bid adieu. They converse apart.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: What, was your vizard made without a tongue?

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: I know the reason, lady, why you ask.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: O for your reason! quickly, sir; I long.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: You have a double tongue within your mask,
And would afford my speechless vizard half.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: Veal, quoth the Dutchman. Is not “veal” a calf?

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: A calf, fair lady!

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: No, a fair lord calf.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Let's part the word.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: No, I'll not be your half:
Take all, and wean it; it may prove an ox.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: Look, how you butt yourself in these sharp mocks!
Will you give horns, chaste lady? do not so.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: Then die a calf, before your horns do grow.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: One word in private with you, ere I die.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: Bleat softly then; the butcher hears you cry. They converse apart.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: The tongues of mocking wenches are as keen
As is the razor's edge invisible.
Cutting a smaller hair than may be seen,
Above the sense of sense; so sensible
Seemeth their conference; their conceits have wings
Fleeter than arrows, bullets, wind, thought, swifter things.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Not one word more, my maids; break off, break off.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: By heaven, all dry-beaten with pure scoff!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Farewell, mad wenches; You have simple wits.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Twenty adieus, my frozen Muscovits. Exeunt King, Lords, and Blackamoors.
Are these the breed of wits so wondered at?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Tapers they are, with your sweet breaths puffed out.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Well-liking wits they have; gross, gross; fat, fat.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: O poverty in wit, kingly-poor flout!
Will they not, think you, hang themselves tonight?
Or ever, but in vizards, show their faces?
This pert Berowne was out of countenance quite.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: They were all in lamentable cases!
The king was weeping-ripe for a good word.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Berowne did swear himself out of all suit.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: Dumaine was at my service, and his sword:
No point, quoth I; my servant straight was mute.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: Lord Longaville said, I came o'er his heart;
And trow you what he called me?

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Qualm, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: Yes, in good faith.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Go, sickness as thou art!

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Well, better wits have worn plain statute-caps.
But will you hear? the king is my love sworn.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: And quick Berowne hath plighted faith to me.

sp.speaker: Katharine
sp.l: And Longaville was for my service born.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: Dumaine is mine, as sure as bark on tree.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Madam, and pretty mistresses, give ear:
Immediately they will again be here
In their own shapes; for it can never be
They will digest this harsh indignity.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Will they return?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: They will, they will, God knows,
And leap for joy, though they are lame with blows:
Therefore change favours; and, when they repair,
Blow like sweet roses in this summer air.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: How blow? how blow? speak to be understood.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Fair ladies masked are roses in their bud;
Dismasked, their damask sweet commixture shown,
Are angels vailing clouds, or roses blown.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Avaunt, perplexity! What shall we do,
If they return in their own shapes to woo?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Good madam, if by me you'll be advised,
Let's mock them still, as well known as disguised:
Let us complain to them what fools were here,
Disguised like Muscovites, in shapeless gear;
And wonder what they were and to what end
Their shallow shows and prologue vilely penned
And their rough carriage so ridiculous,
Should be presented at our tent to us.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Ladies, withdraw: the gallants are at hand.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Whip to our tents, as roes run o'er land. Exeunt Princess, Rosaline, Katharine, and Maria. Re-enter the King, Berowne, LONGAVILLE, and Dumaine, in their proper habits.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Fair sir, God save you! Where's the princess?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Gone to her tent. Please it your majesty
Command me any service to her thither?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: That she vouchsafe me audience for one word.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: I will; and so will she, I know, my lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: This fellow pecks up wit as pigeons pease,
And utters it again when God doth please:
He is wit's pedlar, and retails his wares
At wakes and wassails, meetings, markets, fairs;
And we that sell by gross, the Lord doth know,
Have not the grace to grace it with such show.
This gallant pins the wenches on his sleeve;
Had he been Adam, he had tempted Eve;
'A can carve too, and lisp: why, this is he
That kissed his hand away in courtesy;
This is the ape of form, monsieur the nice,
That, when he plays at tables, chides the dice
In honourable terms: nay, he can sing
A mean most meanly; and in hushering
Mend him who can: the ladies call him sweet;
The stairs, as he treads on them, kiss his feet:
This is the flower that smiles on every one,
To show his teeth as white as whale's bone;
And consciences, that will not die in debt,
Pay him the due of honey-tongued Boyet.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: A blister on his sweet tongue, with my heart,
That put Armado's page out of his part!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: See where it comes! Behaviour, what wert thou
Till this madman showed thee? and what art thou now? Re-enter the Princess, ushered by BOYET; ROSALINE, MARIA, and KATHARINE.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: All hail, sweet madam, and fair time of day!

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: “Fair” in “all hail” is foul, as I conceive.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Construe my speeches better, if you may.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Then wish me better; I will give you leave.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: We came to visit you, and purpose now
To lead you to our court; vouchsafe it then.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: This field shall hold me; and so hold your vow:
Nor God, nor I, delights in perjured men.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Rebuke me not for that which you provoke:
The virtue of your eye must break my oath.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: You nickname virtue: vice you should have spoke;
For virtue's office never breaks men's troth.
Now by my maiden honour, yet as pure
As the unsallied lily, I protest,
A world of torments though I should endure,
I would not yield to be your house's guest;
So much I hate a breaking cause to be
Of heavenly oaths, vowed with integrity.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: O, you have lived in desolation here,
Unseen, unvisited, much to our shame.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Not so, my lord; it is not so, I swear;
We have had pastimes here and pleasant game:
A mess of Russians left us but of late.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: How, madam! Russians!

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Ay, in truth, my lord;
Trim gallants, full of courtship and of state.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Madam, speak true. It is not so, my lord:
My lady, to the manner of the days,
In courtesy gives undeserving praise.
We four indeed confronted were with four
In Russian habit: here they stayed an hour,
And talked apace; and in that hour, my lord.
They did not bless us with one happy word.
I dare not call them fools; but this I think,
When they are thirsty, fools would fain have drink.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: This jest is dry to me. Gentle sweet,
Your wit makes wise things foolish: when we greet,
With eyes best seeing, heaven's fiery eye,
By light we lose light: your capacity
Is of that nature that to your huge store
Wise things seem foolish and rich things but poor.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: This proves you wise and rich, for in my eye, —

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: I am a fool, and full of poverty.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: But that you take what doth to you belong,
It were a fault to snatch words from my tongue.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: O, I am yours, and all that I possess!

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: All the fool mine?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: I cannot give you less.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Which of the vizards was it that you wore?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Where? when? what vizard? why demand you this?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: There, then, that vizard; that superfluous case
That hid the worse and showed the better face.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: We were descried; they'll mock us now downright.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Let us confess and turn it to a jest.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Amazed, my lord? why looks your highness sad?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Help, hold his brows! he'll swoon! Why look you pale?
Sea-sick, I think, coming from Muscovy.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Thus pour the stars down plagues for perjury.
Can any face of brass hold longer out?
Here stand I: lady, dart thy skill at me;
Bruise me with scorn, confound me with a flout;
Thrust thy sharp wit quite through my ignorance;
Cut me to pieces with thy keen conceit;
And I will wish thee never more to dance,
Nor never more in Russian habit wait.
O, never will I trust to speeches penned,
Nor to the motion of a schoolboy's tongue,
Nor never come in vizard to my friend,
Nor woo in rhyme, like a blind harper's song!
Taffeta phrases, silken terms precise,
Threepiled hyperboles, spruce affection,
Figures pedantical; these summer flies
Have blown me full of maggot ostentation:
I do forswear them; and I here protest,
By this white glove, — how white the hand, God knows! —
Henceforth my wooing mind shall be expressed
In russet yeas and honest kersey noes:
And, to begin, wench, — so God help me, la! —
My love to thee is sound, sans crack or flaw.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Sans sans, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Yet I have a trick
Of the old rage: bear with me, I am sick;
I'll leave it by degrees. Soft, let us see:
Write, “Lord have mercy on us” on those three;
They are infected; in their hearts it lies;
They have the plague, and caught it of your eyes;
These lords are visited; you are not free,
For the Lord's tokens on you do I see.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: No, they are free that gave these tokens to us.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Our states are forfeit: seek not to undo us.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: It is not so; for how can this be true,
That you stand forfeit, being those that sue?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Peace! for I will not have to do with you.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Nor shall not, if I do as I intend.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Speak for yourselves; my wit is at an end.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Teach us, sweet madam, for our rude transgression
Some fair excuse.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: The fairest is confession.
Were not you here but even now disguised?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Madam, I was.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: And were you well advised?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: I was, fair madam.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: When you then were here,
What did you whisper in your lady's ear?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: That more than all the world I did respect her.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: When she shall challenge this, you will reject her.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Upon mine honour, no.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Peace, peace! forbear:
Your oath once broke, you force not to forswear.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Despise me, when I break this oath of mine.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: I will: and therefore keep it. Rosaline,
What did the Russian whisper in your ear?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Madam, he swore that he did hold me dear
As precious eyesight, and did value me
Above this world; adding thereto moreover
That he would wed me, or else die my lover.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: God give thee joy of him! the noble lord
Most honourably doth uphold his word.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: What mean you, madam? by my life, my troth,
I never swore this lady such an oath.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: By heaven, you did; and to confirm it plain,
You gave me this: but take it, sir, again.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: My faith and this the princess I did give:
I knew her by this jewel on her sleeve.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Pardon me, sir, this jewel did she wear;
And Lord Berowne, I thank him, is my dear.
What, will you have me, or your pearl again?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Neither of either; I remit both twain.
I see the trick an't: here was a consent
Knowing aforehand of our merriment,
To dash it like a Christmas comedy:
Some carry-tale, some please-man, some slight zany,
Some mumble-news, some trencher-knight, some Dick,
That smiles his cheek in years and knows the trick
To make my lady laugh when she's disposed,
Told our intents before; which once disclosed,
The ladies did change favours: and then we,
Following the signs, wooed but the sign of she.
Now, to our perjury to add more terror,
We are again forsworn, in will and error.
Much upon this 'tis: and might not you To Boyet.
Forestall our sport, to make us thus untrue?
Do not you know my lady's foot by the squier,
And laugh upon the apple of her eye?
And stand between her back, sir, and the fire,
Holding a trencher, jesting merrily?
You put our page out: go, you are allowed;
Die when you will, a smock shall be your shroud.
You leer upon me, do you? there's an eye
Wounds like a leaden sword.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Full merrily
Hath this brave manage, this career, been run.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Lo, he is tilting straight! Peace! I have done. Enter COSTARD.
Welcome, pure wit! thou partest a fair fray.

lg.l: O Lord, sir, they would know
Whether the three Worthies shall come in or no.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: What, are there but three?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: No, sir; but it is vara fine,
For every one pursents three.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: And three times thrice is nine.

sp.speaker: Costard

lg.l: Not so, sir; under correction, sir; I hope it is not so.
You cannot beg us, sir, I can assure you, sir; we know what we know:

sp.l: I hope, sir, three times thrice, sir, —

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Is not nine.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Under correction, sir, we know whereuntil it doth
amount.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: By Jove, I always took three threes for nine.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: O Lord, sir, it were pity you should get your living
by reckoning, sir.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: How much is it?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: O Lord, sir, the parties themselves, the actors,
sir, will show whereuntil it doth amount: for
mine own part, I am, as they say, but to parfect one
man in one poor man, Pompion the Great, sir.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Art thou one of the Worthies?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: It pleased them to think me worthy of Pompey the
Great: for mine own part, I know not the degree of the
Worthy, but I am to stand for him.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Go bid them prepare.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: We will turn it finely off, sir; we will take some care. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Berowne, they will shame us: let them not approach.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: We are shame-proof, my lord: and 'tis some policy
To have one show worse than the king's and his company.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: I say they shall not come.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Nay, my good lord, let me o'errule you now:
That sport best pleases that doth least know how:
Where zeal strives to content, and the contents
Dies in the zeal of that which it presents:
Their form confounded makes most form in mirth,
When great things labouring perish in their birth.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: A right description of our sport, my lord. Enter ARMADO.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Anointed, I implore so much expense of thy royal sweet
breath as will utter a brace of words.
sp.stage: Converse apart wiih the King, and delivers him a paper.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.ab: Doth this man serve God?

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Why ask you?

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.ab: 'A speaks not like a man of God his making.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: That is all one, my fair, sweet, honey monarch;
for, I protest, the schoolmaster is exceeding
fantastical; too too vain, too too vain: but we
will put it, as they say, to fortuna de la guerra. I
wish you the peace of mind, most royal couplement!

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: Here is like to be a good presence of Worthies.
He presents Hector of Troy; the swain, Pompey
the Great; the parish curate, Alexander; Armado's
page, Hercules; the pedant, Judas Maccabaeus:
sp.l: And if these four Worthies in their first show thrive,
These four will change habits, and present the other five.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: There is five in the first show.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: You are deceived; 'tis not so.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: The pedant, the braggart, the hedgepriest, the fool
and the boy: —
sp.l: Abate throw at novum, and the whole world again
Cannot pick out five such, take each one in his vein.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: The ship is under sail, and here she comes amain. Enter COSTARD, for Pompey.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: I Pompey am, —

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: You lie, you are not he.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: I Pompey am, —

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: With libbard's head on knee.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Well said, old mocker: I must needs be friends with thee.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: I Pompey am, Pompey surnamed the Big, —

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: The Great.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.l: It is, “Great,” sir: — Pompey surnamed the Great;
That oft in field, with targe and shield, did make my foe to sweat:
And travelling along this coast, I here am come by chance,
And lay my arms before the legs of this sweet lass of France.
If your ladyship would say, “Thanks, Pompey,” I had done.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.ab: Great thanks, great Pompey.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: 'Tis not so much worth; but I hope I was perfect: I
made a little fault in “Great.”

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: My hat to a halfpenny, Pompey proves the best Worthy.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.l: When in the world I lived, I was the world's commander;
By east, west, north, and south, I spread my conquering might:
My scutcheon plain declares that I am Alisander, —

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Your nose says, no, you are not; for it stands too right.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Your nose smells “no” in this, most tender-smelling knight.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: The conqueror is dismayed. Proceed. good Alexander.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.l: When in the world I lived, I was the world's commander, —

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: Most true, 'tis right; you were so, Alisander.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Pompey the Great, —

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Your servant, and Costard.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Take away the conqueror, take away Alisander.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: O, sir, you have overthrown Alisander the conqueror!
You will be scraped out of the painted cloth for
this: your lion, that holds his poll-axe sitting
on a close-stool, will be given to Ajax: he will
be the ninth Worthy. A conqueror, and afeard to
speak! run away for shame, Alisander.
There, an't shall please you; a foolish mild man;
an honest man, look you, and soon dashed. He is
a marvellous good neighbour, faith, and a very
good bowler: but, for Alisander, — alas, you see
how 'tis, — a little o'erparted. But there are
Worthies a-coming will speak their mind in some other
sort.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.ab: Stand aside, good Pompey.
sp.stage: Enter HOLOFERNES, for Judas; and MOTH, for Hercules.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.l: Great Hercules is presented by this imp,
Whose club killed Cerberus, that three-headed canis;
And when he was a babe, a child, a shrimp,
Thus did he strangle serpents in his manus.
Quoniam he seemeth in minority,
Ergo I come with this apology.
Keep some state in thy exit, and vanish. Moth retires.
Judas I am, —

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: A Judas!

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Not Iscariot, sir.
sp.l: Judas I am, ycleped Maccabaeus.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: Judas Maccabaeus clipped is plain Judas.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: A kissing traitor. How art thou proved Judas?

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.l: Judas I am, —

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: The more shame for you, Judas.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: What mean you, sir?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.ab: To make Judas hang himself.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: Begin, sir; you are my elder.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Well followed: Judas was hanged on an elder.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: I will not be put out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Because thou hast no face.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: What is this?

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.ab: A cittern-head.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: The head of a bodkin.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: A Death's face in a ring.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.ab: The face of an old Roman coin, scarce seen.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.ab: The pommel of Caesar's falchion.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: The carved-bone face on a flask.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Saint George's half-cheek in a brooch.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: Ay, and in a brooch of lead.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Ay, and worn in the cap of a tooth-drawer. And now
forward; for we have put thee in countenance.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: You have put me out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: False; we have given thee faces.

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.ab: But you have outfaced them all.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: An thou wert a lion, we would do so.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.ab: Therefore, as he is an ass, let him go. And so adieu,
sweet Jude! nay, why dost thou stay?

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: For the latter end of his name.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: For the ass to the Jude; give it him: — Jud-as, away!

sp.speaker: Holofernes
sp.l: This is not generous, not gentle, not humble.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.l: A light for Monsieur Judas! it grows dark, he may stumble. Hol. retires.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Alas, poor Maccabaeus, how hath he been baited! Enter ARMADO, for Hector.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Hide thy head, Achilles: here comes Hector in arms.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: Though my mocks come home by me, I will now be merry.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: Hector was but a Troyan in respect of this.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.ab: But is this Hector?

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: I think Hector was not so clean-timbered.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.ab: His leg is too big for Hector's.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: More calf, certain.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.ab: No; he is best indued in the small.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: This cannot be Hector.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: He's a god or a painter; for he makes faces.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.l: The armipotent Mars, of lances the
almighty,
Gave Hector a gift, —

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: A gilt nutmeg.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: A lemon.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.ab: Stuck with cloves.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: No, cloven.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Peace! —
sp.l: The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty,
Gave Hector a gift, the heir of Ilion;
A man so breathed, that certain he would fight; yea
From morn till night, out of his pavilion,
I am that flower, —

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: That mint.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: That columbine.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Sweet Lord Longaville, rein thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.ab: I must rather give it the rein, for it runs against
Hector.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: Ay, and Hector's a greyhound.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: The sweet war-man is dead and rotten; sweet
chucks, beat not the bones of the buried: when
he breathed, he was a man. But I will forward
with my device.
Sweet royalty, bestow on me the sense of hearing.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.ab: Speak, brave Hector: we are much delighted.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I do adore thy sweet grace's slipper.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.ab: Loves her by the foot.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: He may not by the yard.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: This Hector far surmounted Hannibal, the party is
gone, —

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Fellow Hector, she is gone; she is two months on her
way.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: What meanest thou?

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Faith, unless you play the honest Troyan, the
poor wench is cast away: she's quick; the child brags
in her belly already:
'tis yours.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Dost thou infamonize me among potentates? thou shalt
die.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: Then shall Hector be whipped for Jaquenetta that
is quick by him and hanged for Pompey that is dead by
him.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: Most rare Pompey!

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.ab: Renowned Pompey!

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Greater than great, great, great, great Pompey! Pompey
the Huge!

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: Hector trembles.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Pompey is moved. More Ates, more Ates! stir them on!
stir them on!

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: Hector will challenge him.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: Ay, if 'a have no more man's blood in his belly than
will sup a flea.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: By the north pole, I do challenge thee.

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: I will not fight with a pole, like a northern
man: I'll slash; I'll do it by the sword. I bepray
you, let me borrow my arms again.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: Room for the incensed Worthies!

sp.speaker: Costard
sp.ab: I'll do it in my shirt.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: Most resolute Pompey!

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.ab: Master, let me take you a buttonhole lower. Do
you not see Pompey is uncasing for the combat? What
mean you? You will lose your reputation.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Gentlemen and soldiers, pardon me; I will not combat
in my shirt.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: You may not deny it: Pompey hath made the challenge.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Sweet bloods, I both may and will.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.ab: What reason have you for't?

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: The naked truth of it is, I have no shirt; I go
woolward for penance.

sp.speaker: Boyet
sp.ab: True, and it was enjoined him in Rome for want
of linen: since when, I'll be sworn, he wore none
but a dishclout of Jaquenetta's, and that 'a wears
next his heart for a favour.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: God save you, madam!

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Welcome, Mercade;
But that thou interrupt'st our merriment.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am sorry, madam; for the news I bring
Is heavy in my tongue. The king your father —

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Dead, for my life!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Even so; my tale is told.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Worthies, away! the scene begins to cloud.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: For mine own part, I breathe free breath. I have
seen the day of wrong through the little hole of
discretion, and I will right myself like a soldier.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: How fares your majesty?

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Boyet, prepare; I will away tonight.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Madam, not so; I do beseech you, stay.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Prepare, I say. I thank you, gracious lords,
For all your fair endeavours; and entreat,
Out of a new-sad soul, that you vouchsafe
In your rich wisdom to excuse or hide
The liberal opposition of our spirits,
If overboldly we have borne ourselves
In the converse of breath: your gentleness
Was guilty of it. Farewell, worthy lord!
A heavy heart bears not a humble tongue:
Excuse me so, coming too short of thanks
For my great suit so easily obtained.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: The extreme parts of time extremely forms
All causes to the purpose of his speed,
And often at his very loose decides
That which long process could not arbitrate:
And though the mourning brow of progeny
Forbid the smiling courtesy of love
The holy suit which fain it would convince,
Yet, since love's argument was first on foot,
Let not the cloud of sorrow justle it
From what it purposed; since, to wail friends lost
Is not by much so wholesome-profitable
As to rejoice at friends but newly found.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: I understand you not: my griefs are double.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Honest plain words best pierce the ear of grief;
And by these badges understand the king.
For your fair sakes have we neglected time,
Played foul play with our oaths: your beauty, ladies,
Hath much deformed us, fashioning our humours
Even to the opposed end of our intents:
And what in us hath seemed ridiculous, —
As love is full of unbefitting strains,
All wanton as a child, skipping and vain,
Formed by the eye and therefore, like the eye,
Full of straying shapes, of habits and of forms,
Varying in subjects as the eye doth roll
To every varied object in his glance:
Which parti-coated presence of loose love
Put on by us, if, in your heavenly eyes,
Have misbecomed our oaths and gravities,
Those heavenly eyes, that look into these faults,
Suggested us to make. Therefore, ladies,
Our love being yours, the error that love makes
Is likewise yours: we to ourselves prove false,
By being once false for ever to be true
To those that make us both, — fair ladies, you:
And even that falsehood, in itself a sin,
Thus purifies itself and turns to grace.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: We have received your letters full of love;
Your favours, ambassadors of love;
And, in our maiden council, rated them
At courtship, pleasant jest and courtesy,
As bombast and as lining to the time:
But more devout than this in our respects
Have we not been; and therefore met your loves
In their own fashion, like a merriment.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: Our letters, madam, showed much more than jest.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: So did our looks.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: We did not quote them so.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Now, at the latest minute of the hour,
Grant us your loves.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: A time, methinks, too short
To make a world-without-end bargain in.
No, no, my lord, your grace is perjured much,
Full of dear guiltiness; and therefore this:
If for my love, as there is no such cause,
You will do aught, this shall you do for me:
Your oath I will not trust; but go with speed
To some forlorn and naked hermitage,
Remote from all the pleasures of the world;
There stay until the twelve celestial signs
Have brought about the annual reckoning.
If this austere insociable life
Change not your offer made in heat of blood;
If frosts and fasts, hard lodging and thin weeds
Nip not the gaudy blossoms of your love,
But that it bear this trial and last love;
Then, at the expiration of the year,
Come challenge me, challenge me by these deserts,
And, by this virgin palm now kissing thine,
I will be thine; and till that instant shut
My woeful self up in a mourning house,
Raining the tears of lamentation
For the remembrance of my father's death.
If this thou do deny, let our hands part,
Neither entitled in the other's heart.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: If this, or more than this, I would deny,
To flatter up these powers of mine with rest.
The sudden hand of death close up mine eye!
Hence, hermit then: my heart is in thy breast.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: And what to me, my love? and what to me?

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: You must be purged too, your sins are racked,
You are attaint with faults and perjury:
Therefore if you my favour mean to get,
A twelvemonth shall you spend, and never rest,
But seek the weary beds of people sick.

lg.l: But what to me, my love? but what to me?
A wife?
A beard, fair health, and honesty;
With threefold love I wish you all these three.

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.l: O, shall I say, I thank you, gentle wife?

lg.l: Not so, my lord; a twelvemonth and a day
I'll mark no words that smooth-faced wooers say:
Come when the king doth to my lady come;
Then, if I have much love, I'll give you some.
I'll serve thee true and faithfully till then.
Yet swear not, lest ye be forsworn again.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: What says Maria?

lg.l: At the twelvemonth's end
I'll change my black gown for a faithful friend.

sp.speaker: Longaville
sp.l: I'll stay with patience; but the time is long.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: The liker you; few taller are so young.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Studies my lady? mistress, look on me;
Behold the window of my heart, mine eye,
What humble suit attends thy answer there:
Impose some service on me for thy love.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Oft have I heard of you, my Lord Berowne,
Before I saw you; and the world's large tongue
Proclaims you for a man replete with mocks,
Full of comparisons and wounding flouts,
Which you on all estates will execute
That lie within the mercy of your wit.
To weed this wormwood from your fructful brain,
And therewithal to win me, if you please,
Without the which I am not to be won,
You shall this twelvemonth term from day to day
Visit the speechless sick and still converse
With groaning wretches; and your task shall be,
With all the fierce endeavour of your wit
To enforce the pained impotent to smile.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: To move wild laughter in the throat of death?
It cannot be; it is impossible:
Mirth cannot move a soul in agony.

sp.speaker: Rosaline
sp.l: Why, that's the way to choke a gibing spirit,
Whose influence is begot of that loose grace
Which shallow laughing hearers give to fools:
A jest's prosperity lies in the ear
Of him that hears it, never in the tongue
Of him that makes it: then, if sickly ears,
Deafed with the clamours of their own dear groans,
Will hear your idle scorns, continue then,
And I will have you and that fault withal;
But if they will not, throw away that spirit,
And I shall find you empty of that fault,
Right joyful of your reformation.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: A twelvemonth! well; befall what will befall,
I'll jest a twelvemonth in an hospital.

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.l: Ay, sweet my lord; and so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: No, madam; we will bring you on your way.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: Our wooing doth not end like an old play;
Jack hath not Jill: these ladies' courtesy
Might well have made our sport a comedy.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.l: Come, sir, it wants a twelvemonth and a day,
And then 'twill end.

sp.speaker: Berowne
sp.l: That's too long for a play. Re-enter ARMADO.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Sweet majesty, vouchsafe me, —

sp.speaker: Princess
sp.ab: Was not that Hector?

sp.speaker: Dumain
sp.ab: The worthy knight of Troy.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: I will kiss thy royal finger, and take leave. I
am a votary; I have vowed to Jaquenetta to hold
the plough for her sweet love three year. But,
most esteemed greatness, will you hear the dialogue
that the two learned men have compiled in praise
of the owl and the cuckoo? it should have followed in
the end of our show.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand
sp.ab: Call them forth quickly; we will do so.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: Holla! approach.
sp.stage: Re-enter HOLOFERNES, NATHANIEL, MOTH, COSTARD, and others.
sp.ab: This side is Hiems, Winter, this Ver, the Spring;
the one maintained by the owl, the other by the
cuckoo. Ver, begin.

lg.l: When daisies pied and violets blue
And lady-smocks all silver-white
And cuckoo-buds of yellow hue
Do paint the meadows with delight,
The cuckoo then, on every tree,
Mocks married men; for thus sings he,
Cuckoo;
Cuckoo, cuckoo: O word of fear,
Unpleasing to a married ear!
When shepherds pipe on oaten straws
And merry larks are ploughmen's clocks,
When turtles tread, and rooks, and daws,
And maidens bleach their summer smocks,
The cuckoo then, on every tree,
Mocks married men; for thus sings he,
Cuckoo;
Cuckoo, cuckoo: O word of fear,
Unpleasing to a married ear!
When icicles hang by the wall
And Dick the shepherd blows his nail
And Tom bears logs into the hall
And milk comes frozen home in pail,
When blood is nipped and ways be foul,
Then nightly sings the staring owl,
Tu-whit;
Tu-who, a merry note,
While greasy Joan doth keel the pot.
When all aloud the wind doth blow
And coughing drowns the parson's saw
And birds sit brooding in the snow
And Marian's nose looks red and raw,
When roasted crabs hiss in the bowl,
Then nightly sings the staring owl,
Tu-whit;
Tu-who, a merry note,
While greasy Joan doth keel the pot.

sp.speaker: Armado
sp.ab: The words of Mercury are harsh after the songs of
Apollo. You that way; we this way.
